AMERICAS TECHNOLOGY: SOFTWARE

We assume coverage of the Software Sector and 12 additional stocks. We are constructive on AI adoption being a positive tailwind to the Software TAM over the next 5-10 years. Datapoints in any given year may be uneven as the ecosystem matures and as competition evolves; nonetheless, we expect signals on uptake will be more positive in 2026. For the infrastructure providers, we believe the key to stock outperformance will be realizing durable revenue growth and better gross margins, by building capacity that is fungible across customers and workloads, and via silicon diversi fi cation; Buy MSFT for Azure revenue revisions and call options on multiple vectors of AI adoption; and ORCL for improving visibility on capex and ahead of a trough in gross pro fi t growth. For the application providers, we introduce a framework to evaluate AI maturity, including stack replatforming, pace of organic and inorganic innovation, and monetization, with CRM (Buy) screening

well. Lastly, we believe outsized value will accrue in the agent orchestration layer that controls and governs agents across multiple vendors, and see NOW as well positioned.

We assume coverage of the Software sector and 12 additional companies. We are Buy rated on Microsoft, Oracle, Salesforce, ServiceNow, Snow fl ake and Navan. We are Neutral on CoreWeave, Figma, Intuit and Workday. We are Sell rated on Adobe and Datadog.

5-10 years. Although enterprise agentic adoption will likely be uneven and creates room for new competition, we believe signals on uptake will be net positive in 2026, and history suggests that software enablers will be able to capture a portion of the value that they create for customers. With Software sector performance now being mixed for several consecutive years, we take a view on what we see as the three primary stock-moving debates in the sector:

Debate #1: Who will convert an initial share of AI compute into a sustainable, n pro fi table business? We expect the next 3 years to be de fi ned by infrastructure software companies converting backlog to accelerating revenue, and pulling levers of optimization to maximize useful life from today's capex investments and drive gross margin up from <40% to 60%+, approaching scaled gross margins in the cloud business before the AI investment cycle. Comments from Microsoft, Oracle and CoreWeave suggest signi fi cant focus on capacity planning and cost e ffi ciencies, and demand signals continue to be positive as token intensity continues to go up. We are particularly bullish on Microsoft's ability to drive upside to Azure revenue in 2026 given its scale and thoughtfulness on business mix and we expect visibility into the mechanics of Oracle's gross pro fi t acceleration will improve (funding and capex through to contract recognition, with a trough in gross pro fi t growth in 2026E).

Debate #2: Will the application software layer be disintermediated? We expect n to see a heightened level of competition between yesterday's SaaS leaders, today's bespoke software providers such as Palantir, and the AI native companies that have enough proprietary IP to scale (i.e. more than simply an LLM wrapper). We believe competition is particularly elevated because a) the start of a new technology cycle lends itself to more build experimentation while the packaged software vendors mature their o ff erings; b) there is a cohort of companies from the 2020-2021 funding cycle (where VC funding was 2x above trend) that may have smaller moats; c) the classic system-of-record stack of database + human work fl ows + user interface is going to look di ff erent when repurposed for both humans and agents, creating a jump ball that requires meaningful tech replatforming from incumbents. We prefer to be selective in the app ecosystem, favoring companies that are further along in repurposing their

stacks, such as Salesforce, over Workday (Neutral, tech stack still evolving) and Adobe (Sell, growth accruing away from the high end). We also think Intuit has a good tech stack but its exposure to idiosyncratic risks in the tax market and the rates cycle keep us Neutral. We view Navan (Buy) and Figma (Neutral, look for contributions from new product cycles) as idiosyncratic share gain stories in travel/expense and design software respectively. Debate #3: Where will the value accrue in the Software stack? Our customer n conversations suggest that every vendor will have agents; as such, the value lies in agent and LLM orchestration that spans the infrastructure, platform and application 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

layers. This makes vertical integration more powerful than in the prior cloud cycle. We see Microsoft as a leader as it is already entrenched in enterprise work fl ows and is innovating with the Agent 365 orchestration layer and being able to arbitrate across LLMs; along with ServiceNow given its IP in work fl ow engines and its ability to take action across di ff erent systems of record. We also see the potential for Snow fl ake to capture outsized share as enterprises modernize their data estates, and given a heightened pace of product introductions. We are Sell rated on Datadog as our industry work suggests increased competition and heightened customer focus on budget optimization, in part catalyzed by new approaches to address AI observability. Please see our separate Microsoft coverage transfer note here. Pricing in this report is as of 1/8/26. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We expect the Software TAM to get bigger as enterprise AI adoption goes up; we see AI functionality as an intrinsic part of the software value proposition, rather than a technology that reduces it. Simplistically, TAM can be viewed as a function of two things: value unlocked, expressed as productivity gains (the more value unlocked, the better for value capture by software vendors); and competition (the more competition, the more returns and margins get competed down to cost).

To be bullish on Software, an investor has to believe the amount of value ultimately unlocked will be greater than the impact from incremental competition - and we do. This is the inverse of what AI datapoints suggested in 2025, wherein the amount of value unlocked disappointed to the downside, and the amount of new entrants and competition surprised to the upside. (The S&P 500 Software Index was up 9% in 2025 vs. the S&P 500 Semis Index up 43% and S&P 500 up 15%). We believe both these two trends may reverse in the next 3 years: competition will likely moderate and there are more datapoints on quanti fi able AI revenue to Software companies.

To consider value unlocked at the highest level, we leverage the work of our GS economics team, which assumes a baseline gross 15% uplift to US labor productivity and GDP following full adoption, equivalent to $4½tn in economic value creation in today's dollars. The team arrives at this estimate by considering the amount of work that can be automated by speci fi c job category. In prior cycles, Software companies have captured between 10-25% of value created. The high end is consistent with industry pricing studies, including work presented in the book 'Monetizing Innovation' by Madhavan Ramanujam and studies measuring the value captured by software companies relative to the value unlocked at a macro level 1981-2012 (Exhibit 3). However, the low end is more consistent with feedback from industry participants, and may also be skewed by some companies embedding functionality for free to capture share or adoption, or by the potential for disruptive new entrants. Assuming 10% capture would drive a $450bn software TAM in today's dollars vs. a base of $1tr in 2025E (~$450bn

applications; ~$500bn infrastructure; ~$50bn in operating systems and enterprise LLMs, per Gartner). Assuming a base case of decelerating growth absent AI, then layering in a $450bn tailwind with a 3% in fl ation adjustment to calculate nominal dollars, suggests a Software TAM of $2.8tn in 2037, or about 30% larger. The 12-year CAGR would go from 7% to 9%. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 Exhibit 3: ~25% of private sector growth gains were captured by Software companies between 1981 and 2012 Source: Byrne et al. (2013), Oliner and Sichel (2000) , Federal Reserve Board, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Within this, we divide the Software TAM into 'sca ff olding' and 'agentic' at 2/3rds and 1/3rds of the TAM respectively. We expect incremental growth of the Software industry to be tied to enterprise AI, and the most tangible way we expect AI value to manifest is in agentic work fl ows. However, we do not see agents as being a binary outcome or turning on in any given year; rather, we expect to see incremental improvement in functionality (and thus productivity gains) over the next decade. We use our customer service math (Exhibits 8, 9, 10) as a ceiling as to the share of TAM that agents capture, as we believe these use cases when text based are the some of the best suited to AI (veri fi able, repeatable): at 100% adoption and 60% de fl ection, our pricing math suggests agents would represent 70% of the TAM. (We think voice-based customer service agents are likely still 12+ months away from being adopted in practice). We assume the median is in the middle at ~35% of the TAM, taking into account a distribution of use

cases that bene fi t from 0%-70%. Our 'sca ff olding' nomenclature comes from the Satya Nadella's November 2025 interview with Dylan Patel and Dwarkesh Patel and captures the idea that the rest of the software stack exists to enable the agents and humans that use it as infrastructure to create a new layer of agentic and human work fl ows. A key variable within this is how much of the pro fi t pool is captured by LLMs . This in turn will likely be a function of to what extent LLMs are di ff erentiated vs. commoditzed. As a starting point, we use the same rule of thumb above that the enabling technology captures between 10-25% of the value created, or $85bn - $210bn in 2037 in this scenario. This compares to Gartner's estimate of the enterprise LLM TAM at $5.7bn in 2024. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Estimated TAM expansion from AI Source: Gartner, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We adapt our Emerging Software framework from 2021 to re fl ect our learnings over the last 5 years, including ~12 months of AI-focused conversations on how the Software stack is evolving . Our key takeaway is that AI is an evolution of the Software TAM that ultimately makes the TAM bigger; rather than a vector that erodes the value that Software delivers to its end customers. Put simply, we recommend companies with clear competitive moats where AI likely raises the barrier to entry, with favorable 12-month stock set ups. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

- Exposure to Secular Growth: The most iconic companies in our footprint have 1. shown the ability to reinvent themselves across technology transitions: consider Microsoft, founded in 1975, harnessing multiple secular waves in personal computing, mobile computing and cloud computing. A meaningful part of our initiation is dedicated to discussing in what ways AI creates secular growth opportunities at each layer of the stack for today's software leaders. The clearest examples so far are in AI infrastructure compute. At the app layer, we are starting to see agents driving productivity gains for knowledge workers in customer service or coding; and with software taking share from the labor budget (as detailed above, our industry work suggests software companies typically capture 10-30% of the value or productivity gains they provide to customers). At the same time, AI is catalyzing an additional wave of cloud migrations as the cloud often enables better data estate hygiene: while many app categories such as CRM are more than 50% SaaS, our industry work suggests only about 1/3 of PaaS/IaaS workloads are hosted

in the cloud. Select assets at the Infrastructure layer are well positioned to bene fi t from both a heightened pace of cloud migrations and new value derived from AI functionality. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Technical Moat: The competitive narrative today is particularly challenging to parse: 2. There is a tranche of companies that were arguably overfunded in the o ZIRP era of 2020-2021 that are under pressure today due to their smaller technical moats. Our sense is these vendors are commonly cited as being displaced by larger platforms. We believe this extent dynamic is best illustrated by 'excess' VC software dollars relative to trend (illustrated in Debate #2); There is an in fl ux of new competition that largely falls into two categories: o frontier models, which didn't capture value in the pre-2023 software stack and now enable a custom-built software stack; and AI native software start-ups, which generally have lower cost bases and more dynamic tech stacks that bene fi t more directly from a lower cost of code (i.e. there is minimal technical debt in their stacks).

As such, a large part of our due diligence has been focused on understanding competitive moat in excess of the cost of replicating the code base: these moats include ecosystems built around a platform, data context that cannot easily be abstracted via APIs, network e ff ects, and scale. These moats cannot simply be eroded by the cost of coding software coming down; in fact, existing Software leaders with a focus on innovation will use today's AI technologies to transform their own tech stacks and compound their moats.

- Unit Economics: The average software company in our sample set has increased 3. gross pro fi t per employee by 35% 2025 vs. 2021, yet LTV:CAC benchmarking shows we are still well below pre-ZIRP highs. In addition, there is a risk that gross margins compress for many companies in the medium term before normalizing, because of dynamics like forward deployed engineers and driving AI adoption before monetization. This dynamic speaks to the importance of using AI to improve unit economics and as a litmus test for whether technical moat translates to pricing power. For software companies that are di ff erentiated, AI should be a tailwind to LTV:CAC and Rule of 40 measures. There are several examples of increased R&D and S&M productivity, and we believe that the ceiling for operating margin improvements is now higher. Competitive di ff erentiation will be the key factor to realizing these ceilings: gains realized uniformly across categories like customer service in competitive subsectors will likely be arbitraged away over time.

We then map these fundamental drivers into our fi nancial model drivers and overlay the medium-term stock set up. Speci fi cally, where does our quantitative and qualitative industry work suggest upside or downside to Street estimates over the next 12 months, and where is there a perception vs. reality disconnect? Our conclusions are summarized in Exhibit 2 above. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We take a selectively bullish stance on the providers of AI compute in our coverage: our view is shaped primarily by the extent to which providers can a) drive better unit economics on their IaaS businesses; and b) diversify their AI streams of revenue across customers and up the stack to include PaaS and SaaS. We are structurally positive on Microsoft as our industry discussions suggest it has the most fungible capex fl eet across customers and workloads, and several opportunities to monetize compute through more sophisticated Azure services and fi rst party use cases such as M365 Copilot. We are tactically positive on Oracle as we believe revenue will accelerate over the next 12 months, gross pro fi t growth will likely trough over the next 12 months before accelerating meaningfully, and visibility will improve into capex, fi nancing and long term competitive di ff erentiation. We are Neutral on CoreWeave as we believe the company is still early in adding more di ff erentiated software to complement their lead

in high-end AI compute.

In October 2025, our Econ team showed that the technological backdrop remains n supportive of AI capex for two reasons. First, AI applications are boosting productivity when deployed. Second, unlocking these productivity bene fi ts requires signi fi cant computational power, especially since models are increasing in size much more quickly than computation and energy costs are falling. In July 2025, our Semis team applied datapoints across the Fortune 500 to estimate n that approximately 14% of Fortune 500 costs could be highly exposed to AI automation through 2030. This cost reduction could unlock roughly $780 bn in NPV savings (tied to the period 2025-2030), delivering triple-digit returns at approximately $350 bn in aggregate AI capex (through 1H25). We believe the next phase of realizing returns on AI capex will in part hinge on enterprise AI adoption driving increasingly sophisticated types of productivity gains.

Demand signals will likely be positive over the next 12 months. Microsoft has commented that it expects to be supply constrained through at least June 2026; CoreWeave has commented that it believes the industry could be supply constrained through the end of the decade. We believe demand is particularly strong right now due to an uptick in query compute intensity for consumer models; for example, due to automatic switching between shallow and deep reasoning with ChatGPT 5, and due to the introduction of image generation tools like Google's Nano Banana and OpenAI's Sora. We also believe the demand curve for enterprise token usage for use cases like coding and customer service in fl ected in the last 12 months: for example, exiting 2024, Microsoft's GitHub copilot was at $500mn in ARR in a market less than $1bn; today the coding copilot market is closer to $5-6bn based on industry datapoints. Lastly, we believe the depth of the frontier model

provider market (our GS economics team counts >20 companies as leading frontier labs) is creating an arms race of sorts across more 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 than one geographic region, such that there is pressure to invest (and we have yet to see material signs of funding appetite waning.

We look for signals on when supply/demand could come back into balance. In a normalizing environment, we see the most direct positive catalyst to be to the application software providers, as the cost of AI compute embedded with AI applications will come down at a faster pace. We see the second cohort of bene fi ciaries as those IaaS providers that have the most diverse footprints across IaaS, PaaS and SaaS, as these providers will be able to capture newer pro fi t pools tied to the evolution of AI up the stack. For companies with outsized exposure to bare metal compute, the key will be to what extent gross margins can be maintained, for example through selling more di ff erentiated PaaS on top of bare metal GPUs (e.g. moving up the stack into software-di ff erentiated AI services has been a priority for CoreWeave M&A and DigitalOcean's organic roadmap). Many companies have guaranteed customer commitments through 2030,

but we believe the potential for renewing customer contracts post 2030 in an era of oversupply or normalized supply/demand at lower gross pro fi t dollars goes up. Factors to watch: The magnitude of capex revisions slowing down; OpenAI monthly active users slowing (we see this as a proxy for one half of the equation for volume of tokens, with the other half being token intensity). Capex e ffi ciencies from new heating, cooling, and compute management 1. technologies; for example, CoreWeave is able to realize up to 20% higher GPU rental pricing per dollar of GPU procured because of its reliability and lower failure rate. Microsoft discusses its level of technology innovation in its new Fairwater datacenter campuses and its ability to drive token throughput per GPU up 30% qoq in September 2025 for ChatGPT 4.1 and 5; Capex fungibility : Microsoft, Oracle and CoreWeave each emphasize the 2. importance of being able to use their fl eets for multiple use cases (training, inference) and multiple customers; this dynamic will be key to mitigating customer concentration risk in the event any one of the large model providers have growth challenges;

GPU depreciation cycles holding at 5-6 years despite new generation GPUs being 3. delivered on a 1-2 year cadence. Recall that CoreWeave renewed a H100 contract in 3Q25 at within 5% of its original pricing, despite several more powerful GPUs having been introduced since 2022. Our industry work suggests many customer commitments for 5-6 years already take into account nuanced workload downshifting plans, such that the risk to the IaaS provider for these types of 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Diversi fi cation at the silicon level will also be key. Currently, Nvidia has ~95% share of the GPU market (and ~85% of the entire accelerator market) compared to Intel at 70% unit share of the CPU market(vs. >90% CPU share in 2015 Exhibit 12). We use market share as a proxy for buyer-supplier power: in other words, higher market share typically commands more pricing power, which manifests as lower gross margin to the IaaS provider. Our Semis team believes merchant solutions will retain the majority share of AI accelerators for the foreseeable future driven by (1) a rapidly evolving AI model development landscape which prioritizes fl exibility and optimization of model training; (2) the premium which AI developers currently place on high-performance solutions to the exclusion of others factors; (3) a far more widespread and mature developer/software ecosystem for merchant solutions. With this context, we note the following paths to diversi fi cation:

Custom ASICs developed by hyperscalers are addressing speci fi c workload and n cost optimization needs. This includes Google TPUs, Amazon Trainium, Microsoft Maia and Meta MTIA. Although traditionally ustom ASICs have been best suited for internal workloads, we have seen examples (such as Apple and Databricks) leveraging custom silicon from Google and Amazon. As a point of comparison, Microsoft has commented on successfully diversifying its CPU share with its Cobalt ARM-based CPU, which debuted in 2023 and was implemented in production workloads in 2024. Liftr Insights third party observability tooling suggests that Cobalt was behind 33% of new Azure VMs in 4Q24.

More customers are choosing AMD as a second source provider , including n OpenAI's strategic partnership announcement in October for 6GW of AMD Instinct GPUs, beginning with the MI450 series in 2H26. Our Semis team models AMD's GPU share expanding from 5% in 2025 to 8% in 2028. In our meeting with Scott Guthrie, EVP of Cloud and AI, at Microsoft Ignite in November 2025, Microsoft noted it is already diversifying its GPU supplier base and expects this to have a favorable impact on pricing into 2026.

Specialized solutions like Groq's LPUs are proving highly e ff ective for inference. n Groq has emerged as a challenger, particularly in the realm of AI inference. Its Language Processing Unit (LPU) is built for LLM inference, o ff ering speed and e ffi ciency advantages over traditional GPUs for these speci fi c tasks. Groq's LPUs are designed to prioritize sequential processing, enhance compute density, and optimize memory bandwidth, which minimizes ine ffi ciencies and maximizes throughput for LLM inference. The company claims its chips can run LLM models up to ten times faster and use a tenth of the energy compared to current alternatives for inference. This chip uses 1/3 of the energy per token of a GPU and Groq believes that over a 3 year period the chips would break even with the energy costs alone of an NVIDIA GPU. Groq is able to do this in part by using shorter, thinner wires which results in less energy expenditure as data moves through

the chips. In December 2025, it was reported that NVIDIA is buying assets from Groq for $20bn, with the goal of integrating Groq's low-latency processors into the NVIDIA AI factory architecture. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

New entrants are leading to an acute rise in competition, against a backdrop of incumbents that vary in their competitive positioning: while many SaaS companies today are entrenched in their respective work fl ows, there are also some that may be less defensible. We focus our competitive comments here on the application layer, as we believe this is where the greatest competitive noise is. Consistent with prior technology cycles, there is currently an in fl ection of new entrants in the AI application space, in turn supported by VC funding. We believe the competitive pressure is particularly acute this cycle because:

Work fl ows are being rewritten, and work fl ow domain experience is one of the key n di ff erentiators of today's SaaS leaders. The user interface is evolving, and user interface is a key building block of today's n SaaS stack. It is becoming easier to port data in and out of systems of record, reducing the n importance of data gravity. There is an open question on to what extent platform companies and LLMs come up n the stack to compete directly with application companies. There is a cohort of companies that were 'overfunded' in the ZIRP of 2019-2022 n that may have smaller moats. Exhibit 15: Excess funding in 2021 and 2022 may have created a cohort of companies that are inherently less di ff erentiated and more exposed to incremental competition Enterprise Software VC funding Source: Pitchbook, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Source: Pitchbook, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Our primary takeaway from our industry conversations is that the success of agentic technology is not binary: adoption will be de fi ned by select use cases succeeding vs. many others failing. Several of our conversations suggest that the MIT study showing 95% of enterprise AI projects fail is actually a feature, not a bug, as experimentation is a precondition of success, and the technology continues to evolve rapidly. We note that Andrej Karpathy (AI researcher, founder of Eureka Labs, and part of the OpenAI founding team) has commented that agentic adoption will happen over the course of the next decade rather than any one year being 'the year of agents' as 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 engineers work to address today's de fi ciencies in accuracy and reliability.

There are three things that we learned in 2025 that help build our framework for assessing where today's SaaS leaders are with being able to capture share of the AI pro fi t pool:

A high pace of innovation is key to addressing agents, both organically and 1. inorganically. Organically, we would highlight HubSpot, which incorporated AI/ML into its o R&D organization as early as 2023. HubSpot formalized its AI development e ff orts into an AI Platform Solutions group, o ffi cially making AI one of its primary colors (de fi ned as a foundational building block). As such, HubSpot will have a centralized group for developing core AI functionality and integrations, while all other product/application groups will be able to leverage this functionality. HubSpot noted that there are several parallels in the types of work fl ows that can be automated across its di ff erent hubs, such as content generation for marketers (that would otherwise start with a blank sheet of paper) and content aggregation for sales (that would otherwise be aggregating information across a myriad of sources and documents).

Inorganically, we would highlight Salesforce, which announced 9 acquisitions in o 2025 (as well as replatforming their base stack in 2024). The old tech stack can evolve into the new tech stack and it may be easier to 2. start with an existing stack than to make a brand new stack backwards or 'human compatible'. The existing tech stack has the advantage of already capturing existing data (structured, unstructured and external) and being entrenched in human work fl ows. AI can then process broader context and unstructured data/external intent signals at a better pace than before. It may be easier to combine both fl ows when starting with the existing stack, rather than starting with the unstructured data captured by AI and going back and substituting or collecting structured data with the necessary context to make thoughtful decisions.

We do not believe the cost of code coming down changes the calculus 3. universally on build vs. buy, although we do expect to see some share capture by custom software in the enterprise. In our view, this is less a question about vibe coding and more a question on internal IT choosing to build enterprise-grade software in house because they believe they can do so at lower cost for better performance. This distills down to the classic question of insourcing vs. outsourcing: while the cost of building the software may go down, the cost and responsibility of maintaining it (even with agentic e ffi ciencies) will still compound over time. Even in a scenario where the cost of maintaining software applications internally goes down, it will also go down at the specialized providers, such that the performance to cost frontier at the specialized provider will generally always be ahead of the in house technology. We see the most likely custom software share capture in the space that falls between typical systems of record (back o ffi ce vs. front o ffi ce, and requires coordination across multiple business

units or teams that may not have been otherwise connected by packaged software). We look to better quantify how the 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 cost delta changes in an AI-enabled world to better illustrate this point in our future work.

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

opportunity : SaaS incumbents lack comprehensive AI functionality, AI natives typically only address a fraction of the broader enterprise problem, and many developers and IT professionals are still early in their learning curves of how to make AI projects successful. At the same time, organizations are having to face decades of sub-optimal data management practices, and compounding security and governance challenges associated with building software on poorly organized data. Each of these challenges should get easier to manage over time. SaaS incumbents will build in more AI functionality, AI native start-ups will broaden in scope (or be acquired by SaaS incumbents), developers will get smarter, data strategy will be cleaned up and security and governance will improve in concert.

We introduce a framework to assess AI maturity based on how far along a company is with replatforming, innovation and monetization, summarized below. Our industry conversations suggest progressing through the three stages typically takes about three years, and while we order the steps sequentially as a starting point based on what we observe in practice, in many cases companies may address steps in a di ff erent order. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Source: Company Data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Please also see our June 2025 report: Generative AI Part XI: Agentic AI expands the App Software TAM. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Vertical integration matters more than in prior cycles. The Software industry has had a handful of large companies that span the infrastructure, platform and application layers and already realize the bene fi ts of vertical integration (for example, better unit economics). We believe vertical integration will matter more in the AI adoption cycle than in the cloud cycle:

Agents traverse the infrastructure, platform and application layers n indiscriminately, instantaneously and more holistically than humans. This means a good orchestration layer needs to span at least two layers of the stack. There is a role for software vendors to optimize across the new pieces of the AI n compute technology stack, such as accelerator processing units (which are a more meaningful piece of the pro fi t pool today and thus can drive meaningful savings via software optimization) and LLMs. For example, we see a scenario where software vendors can arbitrage to the best possible price/performance e ffi ciency frontier between LLMs by benchmarking LLMs for speci fi c use cases and enabling customers to switch out LLMs with minimal changes to their tech stacks. We see two pieces of the software stack that are well positioned to capture meaningful share of the agentic pro fi t pool:

Orchestration layer providers such as Microsoft, Alphabet (covered by Eric n Sheridan), ServiceNow, and Palantir Data platform providers such as Databricks and Snow fl ake n

We believe one of the key limiting factors for AI adoption in the enterprise today is the lack of high quality, well organized data as a key input for AI applications - and conversely, improving the quality of the data estate creates a secular tailwind for next-gen data enablers. Many of our industry conversations suggest a heightened push around data clean up in 2024 and 2025, but our sense is that this is still a limiting factor to adoption because of the challenges with connecting disparate pools of business operations data into a data warehouse, and a singular organizing and governance layer that sits on top of the data warehouse (we simplistically refer to this as the ontology layer, recognizing that there are more speci fi c technical nuances within this). Anecdotally, at the Databricks World Tour in NYC on Nov 13, Databricks estimated that only 40-50% of attendees were Databricks customers - which is illustrative in our view of many organizations not yet having adopted more sophisticated cloud data management tools. Corroborating this, at the database layer, 56% of the

RDBMS market is still on premise as of 2024 (Gartner). Access to talent is also a challenge: enterprises may have assembled AI data teams by pulling from the existing engineering organization (in which case teams are generally lean and/or pulled in multiple directions), or as a new team with a dedicated hiring e ff ort (in which case teams take time to understand the idiosyncrasies of their organization's data estate and org chart). The next challenge after cleaning up the data is fi guring out what to do with it, which in turn drives dynamics at the application layer (discussed above in Debate #2). 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Against this backdrop, Palantir has taken share because of their ability to solve the data aggregation and ontology challenge at the same time. Palantir's US commercial business has expanded from $335mn in 2022 to $1.4bn in 2025E, or at ~60% CAGR. More speci fi cally, Palantir's forward deployed engineers have specialized experience with aggregating and consolidating pools of data, and then mapping these real-world objects into a single view of the business in its ontology layer. Palantir is also very good at landing at reference design customers, building custom software, but then handing these blocks of custom software to its production development engineers who will streamline and generalize them, so they can be used at other customers within the same vertical. This process, coupled with pricing power, drives Palantir to benchmark at ~100 on the Rule of 40, well ahead of the top quartile companies in Software that benchmark at ~40. (Please see our technical deep dive here).

The ecosystem is standardizing around Iceberg tables , which reduces data gravity 1. and makes it easy to e ffi ciently query and manage data in cloud object storage, regardless of where the data is saved. For example, historically, to use Snow fl ake's database management software, customers also had to port the underlying data to Snow fl ake storage. Today, data stored in the Iceberg format in regular cloud storage buckets (such as S3) can be read and queried by Snow fl ake or any compute engine of choice. Recall that Databricks acquired Tabular for over $1bn in June 2024 in part to accelerate the compatibility gap between Iceberg and Databricks' proprietary Delta Lake technology; Tabular was founded by the creators of Apache Iceberg. Snow fl ake has disclosed that about 10% of its customers are using Iceberg today and our industry discussions suggest that enterprise IT teams are pushing for adoption given the fl exibility this gives them for AI projects.

It is becoming easier to vectorize data once it is organized in a modern data 2. warehouse. For example, at Oracle World in October 2025, Oracle noted that it has already taken private data and vectorized it to make it accessible to AI models, if a customer chooses to utilize their data in that way. Similarly, Snow fl ake and Databricks also o ff er native embedding services such that customers can bypass vectorizing at the database layer, and instead vectorize at the data warehouse layer. It is becoming easier to build an ontology layer. Application software companies 3. have invested in better integrations with the data layer, including Salesforce with Data 360 (which automatically enriches, labels and harmonizes customer-facing data before funneling it into Agentforce), and ServiceNow has introduced RaptorDB and Data Fabric to improve the speed of querying and processing for AI workloads. The pace of innovation at Snow fl ake and Databricks, in our view the two leading 4. data platform vendors, has picked up (detailed below).

The platform software layer has always been fragmented, and we expect multiple vendors to continue to win. For example, Snow fl ake and Databricks' run rate revenue combined is ~$9bn, which comprises less than 10% of the total DBMS TAM of ~$120bn. We believe a rising tide toward data platform modernization will lift several boats over the next 1 - 3 years. However, we also believe that switching cost is lower today because of Iceberg: data gravity or storage stickiness is no longer a reason to stay with or standardize on a speci fi c vendor. This increases the pressure to stay ahead of the competition, which could translate to greater R&D intensity or M&A intensity over the long run. It is unclear to us where the next point of greatest switching cost will be - we suspect it may be the governance or data organization layer, such as Unity Catalog for Databricks; or in the agentic orchestration layer and ontology layers directly (detailed below). It makes sense to us that Snow fl ake and Databricks are increasingly positioning themselves as being

a logical place to build and serve up agentic technology, putting them in more direct competition with the application companies. At the same time, SaaS vendors are starting to introduce product that sits in the platform domain where Snow fl ake and Databricks have traditionally operated. These SaaS data clouds are domain-speci fi c - they bundle storage, governance, and AI services directly in the application suite:

Salesforce Data 360 uses zero copy integration to connect and query data from tools n including other Salesforce clouds and third party datalakes, to create a comprehensive view of each customer. The zero-copy data federation provides near real-time access to external data supported by partnerships with Snow fl ake and Databricks. Workday introduced Workday Data Cloud: Workday partners with Salesforce, n Snow fl ake, and Databricks to provide customers with direct, two-way, zero-copy access to their core HR and fi nance data within these platforms. ServiceNow's RaptorDB is a Hybrid Transactional and Analytical Processing (HTAP) n database speci fi cally engineered for ServiceNow workloads. Based on PostgreSQL open-source standards and enhanced through ServiceNow's acquisition of Swarm64 in 2021 (a database software accelerator), RaptorDB serves as the foundational data layer to deliver faster work fl ow performance.

Over the next 3 years, we expect SaaS data clouds to complement Snow fl ake and Databricks, given enterprises use multiple SaaS apps and need a neutral platform of record to integrate across domains. SaaS vendors like Salesforce and Workday will capture value at the application and work fl ow layer, embedding vertical agents directly where business users already operate; Snow fl ake and Databricks will provide the governed, cross-domain data foundation and agent frameworks. Longer term, we expect the true competitive frontier to be where the value from building AI applications accrues: - to domain speci fi c agents within SaaS applications, abstracting the strategic value of n Snow fl ake and Databricks. In this scenario, data platforms would still power storage, integration, and vector search, but the value creation would move up the stack to SaaS vendors that own the end-user work fl ow. Data platforms would likely be more 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

commoditized infrastructure (similar to databases in the cloud era), especially given the commensurate rise of Iceberg standardization; or - to the 'agent platform', in which Snow fl ake and Databricks become the layer where n enterprises build AI agents. Agents would run on enterprise data in bespoke applications, rather than being hardwired into one SaaS domain. Consider a procurement agent that queries fi nance (Workday) and customer pipeline (Salesforce) in one fl ow - this would require a neutral data aggregation across SaaS silos. In this scenario, the data platforms would become the AI operating system.

Microsoft : Microsoft introduced Agent 365 in November 2025 and also has its n Foundry product to enable customers to build a combination of Microsoft-centric and DIY agentic stacks with centralized governance and reliability controls. Microsoft outperforms Google and OpenAI in M365 environments (unsurprisingly), change management, tooling integration speed, predictable pricing models and private networking. ServiceNow : ServiceNow's core IP allows it to build work fl ows across multiple n systems of record, and its Control Tower allows for centralized governance and management that is vendor/agent agnostic. In the security and observability space, ServiceNow announced the acquisition of Armis in December 2025. Palantir : Palantir builds custom ontology layers with best-in-class forward deployed n engineers and has been doing so for over a decade. Please see our tech deep dive here.

On OpenAI competition speci fi cally: our industry checks suggest that OpenAI has aggressively ramped its sales organization to target enterprise accounts for full stack agentic implementations. When we hosted OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar at the GS Communacopia & Technology conference, OpenAI commented that they believe the future of software applications will be custom, rather than packaged, because the cost of building software is coming down. We believe enterprise monetization is a strategic imperative for OpenAI, given the size of this TAM and its investment in S&M and R&D to date. Our conversations with system integrators suggest that OpenAI wins vs. Google AI and Microsoft AI on select functionality such as: tool integration speed, fast enterprise pilot paths for net-new custom apps, not charging an extra platform fee, and having low built-in trace friction for observability and logging. However, Microsoft and Google are ahead on most other criteria, including governance, change management, business rollout speed, enterprise operations readiness and private networking.

The pace of innovation at Snow fl ake and Databricks, in our view the two leading data platform vendors, has picked up . At one point in time, Snow fl ake and Databricks were partners: Snow fl ake focused on cloud-native data warehousing and SQL-driven analytics for business users, while Databricks provided a big data and machine learning platform for data scientists and engineers. Enterprises actively used both - Snow fl ake as the governed repository for structured/semi-structured data and BI, and Databricks as the processing and ML layer for unstructured and experimental workloads. With the launch of Delta Lake in 2019 (and the broader Lakehouse vision), Databricks moved directly into SQL analytics. At the same time, Snow fl ake expanded into data engineering (Snowpipe, Tasks, Streams) and data science (Snowpark). The two platforms began to market competing architectural visions: 1) Snow fl ake's Data Cloud: governed, enterprise-friendly platform for all workloads; and 2) Databricks' Lakehouse:

open, developerfi rst convergence of lake, warehouse, and AI. Snow fl ake and Databricks now compete across multiple fronts: analytics/BI, data engineering and real-time, ML & AI, applications, and transactions. Snow fl ake has signi fi cantly evolved its platform to manage diverse workloads and address the increasing demands of AI workloads by focusing on a uni fi ed, scalable, and cost-e ffi cient architecture, alongside the introduction of specialized AI/ML features and services.

Cloud Data Warehouse Founded by former Oracle data architects, Snow fl ake built a 1. cloud-native data warehouse that addressed the limitations of traditional on-prem systems. Snow fl ake pioneered a multi-cluster, shared-data architecture that separated storage (data in a central repository) from compute (queries run on dedicated, elastic virtual warehouses). This enabled users to scale computation independently from storage. The focus was primarily on BI and analytics queries, with early workloads including reporting/dashboards, batch analytics, and data consolidation across silos.

Data Collaboration In 2016, Snow fl ake introduced Snowpipe, a service for 2. continuously loading data from cloud storage, enabling real-time data ingestion. During this period, Snow fl ake also introduced support for semi-structured data - the introduction of the VARIANT data type allowed users to store and query semi-structured data (like JSON, Avro, and XML) within relational tables without prior transformation, bridging the gap between a traditional data warehouse and a data lake. In 2017, Snow fl ake launched its Data Sharing feature, allowing secure, instant sharing of live data between accounts (without copying or moving) - this evolved into the Data Marketplace by 2020, where providers could publish and consumers could access shared data sets. These e ff orts broadened workloads into data lake for analytics and a networked (and monetized) data exchange platform.

Data Engineering and ML The introduction of Snowpark in 2020 (which allows 3. developers to use familiar programming languages like Python, Java, and Scala to execute code directly within Snow fl ake) enabled more data-intensive applications and expanded the platform's use cases to include data engineering and machine learning. Application Development Snow fl ake introduced the Native Apps Framework, 4. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 enabling developers to build, distribute, and monetize applications within the Snow fl ake Data Cloud. The framework enabled applications to run within a consumer's Snow fl ake account, eliminating the need for data movement and enhancing data security and governance.

Unstructured Data & AI Snow fl ake expanded into AI and unstructured data with 5. support for documents, images, video, and vector embeddings, enhanced by Cortex Services for generative AI and RAG. Cortex AI o ff ers solutions across both a) agents & insights, with agent apps (Snow fl ake Intelligence), agent APIs (Cortex Agents), and multimodal AI-powered SQL (Cortex AISQL); b) processing & retrieval, with unstructured data retrieval (Cortex Search), structured data retrieval (Cortex Analyst), and document processing (Document AI, Parse, Embed); and c) data, with data connectors (Open fl ow), AI ready data and apps (via the Snow fl ake Marketplace), and multimodal data access.

Data Lifecycle All together, Snow fl ake aims to participate across the end to end 6. data lifecycle. Snow fl ake has taken steps to 1) unify data types - structured, semi-structured, and unstructured - under one governance architecture. Building upon prior momentum in Snowpark and Dynamic Tables, OpenFlow-following the acquisition of Datavolo-introduces a multimodal data ingestion fabric that enables seamless interoperability across both structured and unstructured data sources; 2) expand beyond analytics to support all major workloads: warehousing, data lake, engineering, data science and ML (Snowpark), transactional workloads (Unistore, Crunchy Data acquisition), and AI workloads (Cortex); 3) support secure collaboration with Data Sharing and the Data Marketplace, positioning itself as a network for governed data exchange; and 4) become a platform for application ecosystems through the Native Apps Framework - Cortex AI extends this further by infusing AI capabilities directly into the platform.

Databricks has also evolved its platform from a Spark-based analytics engine into a full data, analytics, and AI platform. Founded by the creators of Apache Spark, Databricks was built around Spark focused on creating a uni fi ed analytics engine for big data. It was focused on batch processing, ETL, and large-scale analytics across Hadoop and cloud storage, with workloads focused on data engineering and large-scale analytics. The introduction of Delta Lake and the Lakehouse architecture combined the governance and reliability of a warehouse with the fl exibility of a data lake - this allowed BI and SQL analytics to run natively on raw data. Databricks has increasingly positioned itself as a platform for building and operationalizing AI at scale, and in our view is Snow fl ake's biggest competitor. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Source: Company data Exhibit 22: Timeline of key technical innovations Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Our primary takeaway today is that both vendors have plenty of runway for growth over at least the next 3 years. Based on extrapolating our current understanding of strengths, weaknesses and roadmaps, we think Snow fl ake may have slightly weaker positioning to capture outsized share over the long term, because a) ML/AI workloads are likely to grow faster and ultimately comprise a larger portion of the data management TAM than data engineering/analyst work fl ows; b) Databricks made foundational decisions early on that position its architecture better for these types of 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

workloads, such that customers still view the platform as having a structural advantage in performance and/or cost over Snow fl ake; c) our industry conversations suggest that Snow fl ake has been incrementally less aggressive than Databricks with strategic M&A and organic investments over the last 5 years. Nonetheless, in our view Snow fl ake has made meaningful progress on closing the functionality gap with Databricks for ML/AI workloads and we believe a rising tide toward data platform modernization will lift several boats over the next 1 - 3 years. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We assume coverage of Adobe (ADBE) with a Sell rating (from Buy) and 14% downside to our 12-month price target of $290. Adobe has navigated many technology transitions successfully and has di ff erentiated IP and ecosystem ties across the content supply chain. That said, we see two challenges to Adobe's ability to sustain >10% growth over the next 3 years: 1) Adobe is competitively di ff erentiated at the high end, but a disproportionate amount of growth and new value generated in the market is at the low end, and the risk of the low end pressuring or limiting seat count at the high end is increasing; 2) the barrier to Adobe new user adoption is high: at the high end, feature-rich tools still carry a steep learning curve; at the low end, Adobe must o ff er something better or cheaper than alternatives such as Canva. We believe these dynamics are well understood with the stock trading at 16x 2027 GAAP EPS and Street estimates for NNARR already moderating from -1.1%% in F25 to

-4.5% in F26. That said, we believe we are only near the beginning of a multi-year secular headwind and expect the stock to be under pressure pending clearer signs of stabilization or in fl ection. We look to success with Express and Adobe establishing itself an orchestration layer across LLMs to become more positive. 1. AI is democratizing design, limiting growth in Adobe's core creative professionals base, while outsized bene fi ts accrue to casual creators and business users who can now 'short-cut' to medium-level creations.

The traditional value proposition of mastering Adobe's more technical tools is declining. For decades, Adobe's value proposition rested on a crucial dynamic: a high barrier to entry o ff set by a high return on technical pro fi ciency. The fl agship Creative Cloud suite (20+ apps) - Photoshop, Illustrator, Premiere Pro, InDesign, After E ff ects, and others - o ff er industry-leading precision and control for creative professionals. The high-end creatives who invested years into building deep technical acumen were rewarded with higher-income, defensible skills, and meaningful economic return on their time invested towards learning these complex tools. Adobe has built its market-leading franchise around serving this high-end professional creative base, which today represents ~48% of Subscription Revenue and ~40mn Creative Cloud (CC) users. Creative Cloud also scaled on the back of an accretive business transition to the cloud, together with feature expansion and a broadening creative surface area across photography, design, video, and 3D.

With AI, the sources of value shifts away from monolithic, feature-rich tools toward fl exible, simple, and AI-grounded interfaces and work fl ows layers. As AI capabilities augment the need for complex feature-sets, the initial cost of learning Adobe's tools may no longer justify the value of mastering them. Tasks that previously required extensive training or multi-step work fl ows can sometimes be completed through natural-language prompts or AI-native tools with minimal prior knowledge. For example, upscaling an image which once required 5-6 steps in Photoshop can now be completed with a single click using Generative Upscale. The 'craft advantage' that Adobe's professional base spent decades accumulating may begin to erode over time. To be clear, we continue to see a material gap between AI-generated low-end outputs and high-end outputs from professional creatives, but these outputs will likely exist on a spectrum giving customers more options to trade o ff time, expense, and quality.

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 This translates to limited seat count growth at the high end. Adobe's most lucrative segment of CC power users will likely grow at a slower pace over the next 3 years than the prior 3, or even decline as the premium of technical mastery erodes, automation reduces paid work for professionals, and Gen AI enables lower-skilled users to perform select tasks previously protected by steep learning curves:

Illustrators and Concept Artists (relevant Adobe products: Illustrator, InDesign): n AI is replicating the styles and ideation process previously exclusive to skilled illustrators and concept artists. According to a Society and Authors Survey (2024), 26% of illustrators lost work due to AI, while 37% attributed income declines to AI tools. Graphic Designers (Illustrator): Graphic design, which involves highly task-based n and iterative work fl ows (e.g., resizing, color correction, and changing fonts), is increasingly becoming automated by AI. The WEF Future of Jobs Report forecasts graphic design as the 11 th fastest-declining job over the next fi ve years. On the other hand, UI/UX designers is forecasted as the 8 th fastest growth category, personas less core to Adobe and increasingly served by Figma.

Commercial Photographers (Photoshop, Lightroom): AI-generated photography n and editing are reducing the demand for traditional commercial shoots, where tasks like background replacement, lighting correction, and entire scene creation can now be completed through text-to-image or automated editing tools. More importantly, businesses realize signi fi cant cost savings by utilizing low-cost AI tools instead of commercial photographers that cost hundreds or thousands of dollars a day. Klarna reported $6mn in cost savings in image production by using GenAI tools, while an early 2025 survey from the Association of Photographers noted that 58% of its members have lost commissioned work to Gen AI services (vs. 21% in late 2024).

3D Modelers, Texture Artists, and Visual E ff ect Artists (Substance 3D, After n E ff ects): AI is reshaping some of the most labor-intensive segments of the animation and 3D pipeline within the gaming and entertainment industries. a16z Games' 2024 AI in Game Development Survey found that 70% of game studios are either using or planning to use AI for generating 3D assets (vs. 48% in 2023). Luminate Intelligence's 2025 Animation + AI report showed that 55% of entertainment workers believe that animators will face 'major impact' from AI within the next two years, while 50% believe the same will apply for visual e ff ects artists.

Video Editors / Compositors (Premiere Pro, After E ff ects): AI is automating many n post-production work fl ows such as dialogue clean-up, captioning, and basic visual composition that once required skilled professionals. In a 2024 CVL Economics Survey, 25% of entertainment executives believe that compositors' jobs will be vulnerable by 2026. 2. While the low-end creative market is a large and growing TAM, competition and low switching costs may limit Adobe's ability to capture meaningful share. While most enterprise software categories such as CRM, HCM, and ERP have steadily consolidated as these markets have matured, the creative-tools market has moved in the opposite direction. Over the past decade, it has simultaneously 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

bifurcated - between high-end professionals and low-end casual creators/business users - and fragmented with the rise of a fast-growing UI / UX design category. Adobe has been slower to respond to several pivotal shifts that re-shaped the modern creative landscape.

Web-native, real-time collaboration. New collaboration technology in the browser n resolved key friction points within the product development life cycle. Figma was able to capitalize upon this shift with a web-native, multi-player design environment and is now the industry standard for modern UI / UX development. Casual creators and business users seeking to create visuals with ease. For n non-professional users, traditional creative tools became so powerful and complex that they created a high barrier to entry. With a cloud-native, template-centric, and intuitive UI, Canva enabled 'design for non-designers.' Its drag-and-drop UI, browser accessibility, and built-in asset libraries signi fi cantly lowered the barrier to design, capturing millions of digital natives who wanted to make re fi ned visuals without technical knowledge.

Social media and the rise of creator economy. The rise of traditional social media n in the early 2010s drove a new creator economy (~67M global creators in '25 growing at ~10% CAGR, GSe). New platforms (e.g., TikTok), new formats within legacy platforms (Instagram Reels, YouTube shorts), and embedded editing tools shifted an increasing share of digital creation into the social platforms themselves. These formats reward speed, frequency, and accessibility, which favor simple, embedded, or mobile tools over Adobe's traditionally feature-rich applications.

Canva MAUs vs. Adobe DM Subscribers Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Adobe is investing in the low end of the creative market with Adobe Express, though adoption and growth has been uneven. Adobe Express (rebrand in 2021 from Adobe Spark, originally launched in 2016) was designed to serve non-professional creatives (like students, bloggers, and marketers) seeking simple, fast, visually polished outputs 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

without navigating the complexity of Creative Cloud. Express has scaled slower than category leaders like Canva: Canva captured mindshare of the digital native generation (1997-2012) early, building strong brand equity and a deeply intuitive UX years before Express achieved product coherence. Early versions of Spark/Express were fragmented (stitched suite of prior Spark applications Post, Slate, and Voice with a web version), lacked intuitiveness, and was viewed as a 'repackaged' version of Adobe's professional tools rather than a net-new product tailor made for non-creative professionals. Canva, meanwhile, harnessed a template-centric approach minimizing the 'blank canvas' dilemma, freemium model to drive mass adoption, intuitive UX for frictionless onboarding, and one-click content sharing to drive user engagement - factors we believe Adobe overlooked at the onset.

Express is making progress, we look for further signs of success. For the fi rst few years, Express saw limited product evolution, with most updated focused on incremental UI and feature improvements. Express product enhancements were modest between 2021 - 2023, with most innovations focusing on incremental UI and feature improvements (e.g., added font/color palette recommendations in 2022). However, with the rise of GenAI and unveiling of Adobe's own di ff usion model Fire fl y in 2023, Express has garnered more momentum. For example, the new 2024 Express mobile app integrates Fire fl y deeply across the work fl ow, enabling text-to-image generation, generative fi ll, and text-to-template; drove signi fi cant MAU growth and user engagement (Exhibit 24, Exhibit 25). Further, the recently launched AI Assistant (beta) also o ff ers an attractive proposition for non-creative professionals involved within the content supply chain, whereby the new conversational

AI interface can be compelling to a new generation of AI-native users. We believe GenAI may give Express a leap forward in the product's innovation arc and opportunity to better capture the low end of the creative market.

base. Since 2022, Adobe has prioritized investments in Fire fl y, its integration into Express, and deepening its interconnectivity with the broader Creative Cloud ecosystem. This has simpli fi ed many work fl ows and enabled Adobe to broaden its footprint across business users (e.g., marketers), with 14K+ new organizations onboarded in F3Q25. However, this has also created a strategic tension: as Adobe works to catch up at the low end of the market, high-end professionals increasingly perceive that the company's investments are being diverted away from improving the deep, pro-grade tools they rely on. From our industry conversations, several noted that investment in Express - and the broader AI roadmap - are coming at the cost of enhancing the feature-rich Creative Cloud products that historically justi fi ed Adobe's premium pricing (+25-32% price increase since 2022). Even though the low end and GenAI likely represent Adobe's clearest

near-to-mid-term growth opportunity, the company is investing in a segment that has inherently lower switching costs, viral adoption loops, and prominent players like Canva. At the same time, leaning into the low end risks weakening Adobe's foothold within its long-standing professional user base, potentially eroding the retention and pricing power in core Creative Cloud business. Taken together, we view Adobe to be disproportionately exposed to the parts of the creative market that are growing the slowest, while the fastest-growing segments UI / UX designers, non-professional users, casual creators (e.g., social media 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Canva acquired A ffi nity in March 2024, which marked the company's fi rst push into the high-end creative market. A ffi nity - with A ffi nity Designer (vector-based design), A ffi nity Photo (advanced photo editing), and A ffi nity Publisher (page layouts) - comes closer to addressing Canva's feature gaps relative to Adobe's fl agship products (Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign), allowing Canva to target professional users within the latter's core user base. A ffi nity now o ff ers a comparable feature set for free (vs. $276-$414 per year for CC 'single apps'). Announcements from Canva World Tour 2025 suggest a broader strategic push across the content supply chain. Canva's new Creative Operating System uni fi es its Visual Suite, Canva AI, and platform into an end-to-end ecosystem for both creative and marketing work fl ows. Notable innovations included Video 2.0, which enables near-pro-grade video editing; Email Design, enabling users to create branded marketing emails with ease; Forms that quickly collects end-customer feedback into Canva Sheets that now integrates with an enhanced Canva Code; and Canva Grow, a one-stop campaign engine that helps marketing teams create, publish, and measure content performance across channels. Canva also introduced its Design Model, the fi rst model trained speci fi cally on design logic (structure, branding, hierarchy, etc.), ensuring on-brand creations across the Visual Suite. Together, these innovations signal Canva's investments not only to capture higher-end creative professionals but also to capture more pieces

of the content supply chain.

Figma also plans to capture more pieces of the creative value chain by expanding beyond UI / UX design into adjacent product development work fl ows. While Figma Design is already the industry leader in UI / UX design, the platform spans the product development lifecycle - ideation, design, development, shipping, and promotion. By consolidating these stages within one collaborative interface in the browser, Figma is capturing work fl ows that once required multiple tools and design-adjacent personas (developers, PMs, marketers, etc.). For example, Figma Draw introduced more advanced vector-editing and graphic manipulation capabilities, narrowing the feature gap with professional-grade tools like Adobe Illustrator. More importantly, Figma's strength lies within its centralized design system which is not only tightly integrated with downstream development but also the broader product suite. We believe this well-positions Figma to become the de facto standard across the product development lifecycle. This same foundation also enhances Figma Make, where AI-native

prompt-to-product capabilities leverage Figma's design systems, governance, and enterprise-grade controls to produce brand-consistent, production-ready outputs - capabilities that other AI-native tools lack. One industry expert we spoke with noted that most of the value still resides in design inspection and re fi nement rather than in code generation, and while AI-native tools can produce initial prototypes, the outputs are not production-ready. AI ultimately will bene fi t the designers by lowering the barrier to coding, not by replacing the design work that remains central to the product development lifecycle which happens within Figma. Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 - 3. What would make us more positive: Adobe's opportunity as a design orchestration layer

We believe the single biggest opportunity for Adobe is to become the uni fi ed interface or orchestration layer on top of a rapidly expanding universe of image di ff usion models. As the creative work fl ow fragments across specialized AI models each optimal for di ff erent styles, aesthetics, and use cases - value shifts away from any single model and toward the application layer that can abstract this complexity for users. Similar to our view in broader Software, we believe LLMs may begin to commoditize over the next 24 months. No single model can comprehensively meet the full spectrum of creative needs (Topaz Labs for upscaling, Veo for cinematic outputs, etc.), and the pace of new model releases makes it impractical for users to manually evaluate, compare, and switch between providers. Adobe's broadening ecosystem of 3P models (including recent additions of Comfy UI and Black Forest Labs), coupled with its commercially-safe Fire fl y model, present a unique opportunity. Fire fl y ensures commercial viability

and brand fi delity, while the openness to 3P models positions Adobe as a neutral interface through which creators can access, combine, and seamlessly toggle between the best-in-class models for each task. Adobe's unique advantage lies in the scale and depth of its creative portfolio that spans across photography, design, video, 3D, etc. By embedding AI model interoperability directly across this suite, Adobe can reinforce its hold on core creative professionals and capture the emerging generation of AI-natives.

3P Models Available on Adobe, Canva, and Figma Source: Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, Company data Secondly, Adobe has the scale needed to build custom AI models for enterprises. In addition to supporting 3P models, Adobe recently introduced Fire fl y Foundry - a managed service that enables businesses to work with Adobe to develop custom AI 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

models trained on their own brand assets and IP. Built on Adobe's family of commercially safe Fire fl y models, Foundry strengthens Adobe's position as a content supply chain platform, allowing customers to accelerate content production at scale while preserving brand fi delity and governance. While enterprise AI adoption remains early (we have spoken to some early adopters, but overall 2026 adoption will be key), Foundry could be the key to reducing key barriers by giving organizations a secure path to deploy AI-generated content optimized on their own data without comprising brand standards. We believe this can also position Adobe to accelerate adoption within marketing (Digital Experience) as well as Express across a broader base of business users.

We estimate that the global creative-professional workforce is around ~65M in 2025, earning an average wage of ~$47K (estimated based on applicable employment pro fi les from U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and ILOSTAT), implying an aggregate 'creative labor market' of ~$3.1T. Hypothetically, if AI drives a 20% productivity gain across this pool by 2035, the value of those gains could total ~$617B. In our base-case scenario, taking into consideration Adobe's market positioning and competitive risks as well as industry conversations, we expect that Adobe could capture ~13-18% of that productivity uplift and is able to monetize ~10% of the captured value through upselling subscriptions or consumptive AI services, this could present a $6-12B revenue opportunity and 3-5% uplift to growth. The table below illustrates various scenarios in either Adobe's share of the

productivity uplift or monetizable opportunity, underscoring the structural leverage the company has if it positions itself as the UI for AI in creative work. That said, to become the orchestration layer for AI-native creators, we believe Adobe may still need to strengthen foundational layers: simplify its tooling, enable multi-user collaboration, and allowing work to fl ow freely across the suite.

We recognize that many of the competitive dynamics we outline above are well understood and that the stock has made new lows on GAAP P/E valuation. That

said, we believe that using the bottom quartile PEG is warranted given the slower EPS growth and questions on the durability of its growth pro fi le. Speci fi cally, we see potential scenarios in which Adobe's EPS growth is further pressured if the company invests more around its AI initiatives, or if Adobe's revenue growth falls below 10% if the company loses its pricing leverage with the proliferation of AI tools and increased competitive pressure.
