Adobe's opportunity as a design orchestration layer, detailed in Section 3 above n Faster AI momentum and revenue contribution. In F25, Adobe's AI-in fl uenced n ARR has exceeded one-third of the overall business while AIfi rst revenue accelerated throughout the year. At the same time, Generative Credit consumption in Creative Cloud, Fire fl y and Express has grown 3x QoQ as of F4Q25. If Adobe is able to sustain this momentum onward, scale net customer adds and user engagement at a faster clip than anticipated, this could translate into consumption-based revenue streams that are additive to revenue growth or drive upsell momentum into higher-priced SKUs across the install base. If Adobe is able to execute on its AI roadmap and become the design orchestration layer, we can see a more viable path for durable double-digit ahead.

Sustained pricing leverage across creative professionals. We assume that Adobe's n ability to take price in core Creative Cloud moderates as AI commoditizes parts of the creative work fl ow and competition intensi fi es. Historically, Adobe has successfully implemented price increases on Creative Cloud by enriching the features within the product suite, maintaining high pricing leverage with professional users. However, AI is enabling non-creative professionals to short-cut skills that required 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 high technical expertise, which may erode the pricing leverage that Adobe historically upheld. However, if Adobe is able to successfully upsell users via higher-valued AI capabilities, maintain low churn and stable or rising seat counts despite price increases, and expand seat penetration within enterprises for creative professionals, this could make us incrementally more positive.

- Success with Express. There are signs that Express is seeing more traction in the n past 12 months, based on our conversations at Adobe Max in 2025. If the competitive environment were to become less intense and new product innovations can enable Adobe to capture the mindshare of business users, we would become more positive on Adobe's positioning at the low end of the market. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We assume coverage of CoreWeave (CRWV) with a Neutral rating and 12% upside to our 12-month price target of $86. We believe CoreWeave's purpose-built architecture provides a signi fi cant competitive advantage against traditional hyperscalers and other neoclouds at the high end, and the AI compute industry remains supply constrained. We expect CoreWeave's ability to commit to large customizable deployments while maintaining its speed to market and reliability will continue to drive large deals. We are Neutral for two reasons: a) CoreWeave's positioning at the high end of the market requires best in class execution, including for factors and partners that CoreWeave cannot entirely control, creating a heightened degree of near-term volatility that is magni fi ed for equity holders because of CoreWeave's outsized debt (~6x net debt to TTM EBITDA as of 3Q25); b) CoreWeave is in the early stages

of building out its product strategy to expand up the stack beyond high-density compute, and these levers will be key to CoreWeave's long-term value proposition as the AI TAM diversi fi es beyond high density compute (e.g. towards inference).

- 1. CoreWeave's purpose-built architecture is a competitive di ff erentiator CoreWeave's architecture is a signi fi cant competitive advantage against traditional hyperscalers and other neoclouds, primarily due to its specialized focus on high-performance, GPU-accelerated workloads for AI and ML workloads. Founded in 2017 as Atlantic Crypto, the company initially focused on mining Ethereum using GPUs. Following the 2018 cryptocurrency crash, it pivoted in 2019 to rebrand as CoreWeave and leverage its deep GPU inventory in cloud computing infrastructure. As demand for AI/ML workloads grew, CoreWeave further specialized to become a purpose-built cloud provider for GPU-accelerated computing. This specialization was supported by a critical partnership with NVIDIA, including a $100mn investment from NVIDIA in April 2023, granting CoreWeave early access to cutting-edge GPUs like the H100, H200, GB200, and Blackwell series. CoreWeave has

rapidly scaled its infrastructure, from 3 data centers in 2022 to 41 data centers today, with 250k+ GPUs, ~590MW of active power, and ~2.9GW of contracted power. Beyond raw compute, CoreWeave is evolving into a comprehensive AI platform, o ff ering high-performance storage like CoreWeave AI Object Storage (CAIOS) and integrating developer tools and AI agent training capabilities.

This specialization translates into superior performance, cost e ffi ciency, and optimized infrastructure tailored for demanding AI tasks. CoreWeave competes with the following two cohorts: 1) Cloud hyperscalers including Amazon, Microsoft, Google, and Oracle - compared to these hyperscalers, CoreWeave holds ~1% market share; and 2) Neoclouds, which are pure-play GPU cloud providers. These can be further split between a) neocloud vendors including Crusoe and Nebius (where CoreWeave holds ~70% share); and b) 100+ emerging neoclouds (which generally have smaller amounts of capacity, some of which are white labeled). CoreWeave's architecture e ff ectively di ff erentiates from both competitor cohorts: - vs. hyperscalers: CoreWeave is solely focused on AI compute vs. hyperscalers who n need to balance priorities across their lines of business; for example, Microsoft has

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 discussed balancing its GPU allocations between third party customers vs. its own internal R&D and fi rst party apps. CoreWeave's data centers are purpose-built from the ground up for AI workloads, o ff ering bare-metal access to the latest NVIDIA GPUs. This eliminates the virtualization overhead common in hyperscaler environments, leading to superior and more predictable performance for demanding GPU-intensive tasks. Moreover, its strategic partnership with NVIDIA provides fast time to market for the newest GPUs.

- vs. neocloud giants: CoreWeave is unique among the emerging Neocloud peers in n its deployment of large scale GPUs for single customers (up to +100K GPUs). CoreWeave invests in a strong engineering base and proprietary solutions (such as observability) that have helped build its expertise in this area. Keeping large clusters of GPUs online for days at a time is a di ffi cult technical challenge, especially as the fi rst deployments of next-gen GPU clusters typically see higher failure rates. Our customer diligence emphasized CoreWeave's strong reliability vs. the downtime experienced with competitors, where they saw daily - if not hourly - failure rates. The failure of just one GPU can disrupt an entire training workload, causing hours of downtime, and these errors are compounded at scale. CoreWeave is able to minimize this level of disruption via the granular visibility it has into some of the largest deployments of next-generation

GPUs. In the MLPerf Training v5.0 benchmark, CoreWeave deployed an NVIDIA Blackwell GPU cluster with ~2500 Blackwell GPUs (39x larger than the next cluster submission) and completed the training benchmark over twice as fast as similarly sized GPU clusters using Hopper GPUs. Smaller scale peers do not have the technical expertise to run such complex workloads reliably - this results in up to 20% higher performance on CoreWeave vs. like-for-like GPU clusters from alternative providers, with at least 14% improvement in price-adjusted performance.

SemiAnalysis' ClusterMAX Rating System provides an independent benchmark for evaluating how cloud providers meet the demands of large-scale AI workloads. CoreWeave is the only provider to receive the Platinum tier, according to SemiAnalysis, excelling across security, price for value, technical expertise, reliability backed by clearly de fi ned SLAs, seamless managed Slurm/Kubernetes o ff ering, and best in class NCCL/RCCL networking performance. As a result, CoreWeave is able to command a higher price for managed slurm on Kubernetes clusters (by roughly 10-15%), per GPU-hr vs. their direct neocloud competition (i.e. Nebius, Fluidstack, Crusoe, and Together.ai), with pricing closer to the hyperscalers. Looking forward, SemiAnalysis expects CoreWeave to focus on providing on-demand instances, continuing to develop autoscaling features to support inference at

scale, and maintain the lead in reliability for rack-scale deployments. We provide a comprehensive overview of CoreWeave's results across SemiAnalysis' criteria below. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Based on 2024 compute revenue Source: Company data, Forbes, Sacra, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

The AI Compute industry remains supply-constrained as demand for large-scale training clusters continues to outpace the availability of advanced GPUs, 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 high-bandwidth networking, and power-dense data center capacity. Foundational model developers require tightly-coupled supercomputer-class infrastructure, which only a handful of providers can reliably deliver. For the reasons we detail above, CoreWeave screens as one of the best providers for these types of workloads. Despite pricing at the higher end of AI cloud service providers, CoreWeave has discussed anecdotally that customers have come back to CoreWeave after initially choosing a lower-priced cloud, given CoreWeave's reliability. In this supply-constrained environment, we expect CoreWeave's ability to commit to large customizable deployments while maintaining its speed to market and reliability will continue to drive large deals.

CoreWeave currently has $55.6bn of revenue backlog, with 60% tied to investment-grade customers and no single customer representing more than ~35%. We estimate that CoreWeave has 83%/56%/37% RPO coverage based on 2026/2027/2028 GSe revenue, assuming that RPO is spread evenly across the years (split between 24 month, 25-48 month, and 49+ RPO disclosures). While a portion of the remainder will likely be a function of adding net new customers, we also see opportunities from existing customers expanding contracted commitments (either because they need additional capacity or because of a new generation of chips) as well as CoreWeave's push into more on-demand, pay-as-you go agreements (discussed in more detail below). We also illustrate the potential breakdown of customer concentration based on announced deal values across large customers including Microsoft, OpenAI, and Meta. We note that this breakdown is illustrative given the cadence and timing of revenue recognition may vary, but we believe it may be helpful for approximating customer concentration.

Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research CoreWeave's revenue model is based on long-term, committed take-or-pay contracts (95%+ of revenue), which are typically 3-5 years in duration . At contract signing, CoreWeave typically receives 15-25% of the Total Contract Value (TCV) up front with the remaining recognized ratably over the duration of the contract. CoreWeave leverages the upfront payment to purchase GPUs and other infrastructure components. The pre-payment sits within deferred revenue, while the company's Construction in Progress (CIP) CapEx metric signi fi es the costs related to GPUs before it goes live. The installation period typically takes 3-6 months. Once the infrastructure goes live, CoreWeave starts recognizing revenue on a ratable basis (ex. the upfront payment). With a 2.5 year cash payback period over their average 4-year contract length, CoreWeave 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

aims to drive visibility and a solid ROI pro fi le from such contracts. We consider an illustrative, 4 year contract (that assumes 60% residual value of the capex for the 2 years post contract), funded 15% organically/85% debt (at a 9% interest rate) - based on this contract structure, we estimate CoreWeave's IRR based on a variety of MOIC and EBITDA margin assumptions.

Shift to on demand revenue: In the medium term, we also expect CoreWeave to n expand into more on demand revenue - currently CoreWeave's revenue model remains heavily dominated by committed contracts (98% of revenue), with on-demand o ff erings still in early development stages. The company has yet to go through a meaningful end-of-contract cycle - as such, we expect the base of on-demand revenue to scale from current levels. As larger cohorts of customers move past committed contracts, there is likely to be a layering e ff ect to the company's on-demand revenue base. Customers are likely to use their infrastructure until the GPUs fail, which typically occurs beyond the typical GPU depreciation cycle of six years. After the committed term, we think it's likely that CoreWeave leverages its existing infrastructure for on-demand workloads. While there is a debate around the useful life of older generation chips, CoreWeave recently discussed re-contracting an H100 contract with an existing

customer within 5% of the original pricing. While this may be a function of the ongoing supply-constrained environment, we nonetheless view this as a positive datapoint on the persistent value of hardware and CoreWeave's ability to leverage its GPU base when contracts expire (either in new contracts or for on-demand use cases) at higher margins. Optimize asset utilization and deployment e ffi ciency: Strategies include reducing n the time from infrastructure deployment to revenue generation, ensuring high utilization rates of its GPU fl eet, and repurposing older GPU clusters for less demanding but still pro fi table inference workloads. Software-based solutions: Discussed in more detail below. n

Long-term view: what happens when supply/demand normalizes? While we expect CoreWeave to continue to win share of the AI compute market as supply remains constrained, we expect that more capacity coming online across a number of providers will drive the industry toward supply/demand equilibrium. As 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 supply/demand normalizes and as growth in the market may be weighted away from the high end, CoreWeave's platform strategy will become more important.

CoreWeave already integrates proprietary software to improve the performance of their con fi gured nodes and data center systems : 1) mission control, its cluster health management system providing real-time infrastructure visibility and automated lifecycle management for AI workloads; 2) SUNK, an orchestration system enabling improved identity federation, research segmentation, and large-scale AI workload management; and 3) CoreWeave Kubernetes Service (CKS), for managing distributed AI workloads with fl exibility. This year, CoreWeave has continued to innovate on the platform, adding AI Object Storage, a fully managed storage service designed speci fi cally for AI workloads; and zero egress migration, eliminating data transfer costs and providing real-time migration dashboards for multi-cloud AI development.

In addition to organic investment, CoreWeave is also actively acquiring specialized AI companies to vertically integrate capabilities across the AI development lifecycle , innovating up the software stack; including Weights & Biases, OpenPipe, Monolith, and Marimo. Weights & Biases (5/2025) enables end-to-end developer work fl ows, combining n infrastructure with tools for model iteration, experiment tracking, and inference to develop, deploy, and iterate AI faster. OpenPipe (9/2025) integration has created ServerlessRL, allowing customers to n fi ne-tune AI models on CoreWeave's platform. Marimo (10/2025) enables developers to move from experimentation to production n deployments and of Monolith AI (12/25) expands CoreWeave's platform into industrial applications.

We expect CoreWeave to continue to both organically invest and leverage acquisitions to move up the stack as it positions itself as a full-stack AI service provider addressing the entire AI development lifecycle, while maintaining its focus on purpose-built infrastructure for AI workloads.

We also believe CoreWeave's nascent software solutions can potentially be commercialized. CoreWeave does not currently commercialize its software tools as standalone products but instead integrates them into its infrastructure platform, monetizing through access to the full platform rather than discrete software sales. (For example, its observability software drives as much as a 20% increase in pricing given the higher reliability it drives). While we expect CoreWeave to prioritize scaling its total platform over monetizing incremental aspects in the medium term, longer term we think monetizing some of these tools can provide a growth lever that scales without incremental capex (thus improving unit economics.) In our view, CoreWeave's Mission Control and Observability is particularly unique in the market and thus could lend itself well to commercialization to ecosystem partners or customers that do not compete directly with CoreWeave. This is the backbone of CoreWeave's AI Cloud Platform, with capabilities including fully automated cluster lifecycle management, advanced cluster validation, proactive health monitoring, and rapid

We assume coverage with a Neutral rating and a 12-month price target of $86. Our valuation methodology is based on EV/EBIT to account for CoreWeave's capital intensity and elevated D&A. We assume coverage on Datadog with a Sell (from Buy) and 14% downside to our 12-month price target of $113. We view Datadog as one of the most complete platforms in Observability with a strong track record of delivering customer value, and the Observability TAM is fragmented so many companies can win. However, we expect 2026 to be a year where competition intensi fi es and customers are more focused on observability budget optimization, which is likely to pressure Datadog's fundamentals. Speci fi cally: 1) AI adoption drives an increase in data volume and cardinality (unique dimensions per signal), likely prompting customers to revisit their observability strategy; 2) competitors such as Grafana, Clickhouse and Chronosphere (pending acquisition by Palo Alto Networks) are increasingly focused on capturing share in observability by optimizing customer observability budgets, including via driving lower Datadog bills; we think CrowdStrike and Snow fl ake (announced plans to acquire Observe on 1/8) could also choose to compete more intensely; 3) our

industry conversations at AWS Reinvent in December 2025 suggest a heightened focus from Amazon to capture share of cloud observability budgets. Taken together, we expect the industry to evolve to a more de fl ationary architecture: Datadog will likely either have to innovate into a more e ffi cient tech stack and pricing model, or will capture less share. While we do not take a view on any particular quarter, we expect these dynamics to drive slowing revenue growth and increased opex or M&A intensity, and weigh on the stock's multiple.

Datadog spend at customers may go up before it goes down, and ultimately n settle at a level of spend that is a net positive tailwind. As existing Datadog customers adopt AI, their spend with Datadog goes up; this in turn catalyzes the push to optimize budgets. It is possible that the timing of our call is wrong, such that fundamentals outperform over the next several quarters before customers push to optimize; or that the compounding cohorts of customers that are growing neutralizes the headwind from customers that are optimizing in any given quarter. Illustratively, a 50% reduction in a bill that has already grown from $100 to $250 is still 25% growth vs. base.

Datadog's product lead may be large enough to still win vs. cheaper n competitors. Datadog's strengths across user interface, and go to market; coupled with its product strengths across traces, metrics and logs; position it as best of breed. Newer competitors may o ff er material cost savings, but customers may ultimately decide it is not worth the risk to go with a less established/lower scale or more fragmented tech stack, or a tech stack that requires more engineering resources to manage e ff ectively. This is particularly true for open-source o ff erings that shift the burden of management back to the customer. Datadog may pick up its pace of investment in S&M to increase the quantum of n NNARR in the model over the next 12-24 months, allowing the company to meet or exceed investor expectations for revenue growth, albeit at higher opex intensity. Stock trading action over the past several quarters for the sector suggest that investors value 1 pt of revenue growth more than 1 pt of margin expansion.

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 Datadog's share momentum could improve in Security . We estimate that n Datadog's current product set in Security e ff ectively doubled its TAM - from $20bn in Observability to $40bn including SIEM, Cloud and Application Security. The strategy is still early, and we think Datadog will need to show consistent traction before Security can be viewed a major driver of upside in the model. Datadog has advantages at the data layer, but the security market remains competitive, and the convergence between the Observability and security market introduces both opportunity and risk to the business. We believe SIEM is the most tangible opportunity: SIEM is fundamentally a log-centric, data-heavy product, and Datadog already has penetration in log ingestion, routing, and analytics. Many customers now expect Observability and security logs to live in a single work fl ow rather than in separate systems, which puts Datadog in a structurally advantaged position.

1. AI is catalyzing the next architectural evolution in the AI observability stack Observability has gone through several architectural shifts in the last 20 years, such that leading vendors struggle to maintain outsized market share over time because of the challenges with replatforming and maintaining a dynamic pricing model. This includes the initial market for infrastructure monitoring on prem; the shift to virtualization and log-centric search, alongside the expansion of the application observability market; the shift to microservices with the introduction of APMs and tracing; and innovations in storage and big data.

We believe AI is the next architectural shift because it is more telemetry intensive: customers generate more logs, traces and custom metrics per request. Speci fi cally: Datadog prices in part as a function of cardinality. Cardinality is the number of unique dimensions per signal. Cardinality goes up with GenAI because of the number of prompt variants, tool paths and model versions. At low scale, customers can use sampling to keep the budgets low. However, with AI, the errors become harder to fi nd because rare hallucinations matter and long-tail errors are important. This means that reducing sampling comes with disproportionate risk.

Shifts in architecture drive shifts in competition . Our conversations with ecosystem partners including at AWS Reinvent in 4Q25 suggest diversifying the stack to reduce budget is top of mind. This introduces new competition into the stack, many of which propose new technology to optimize observability budgets, bring parts of the budget in house using open source, and in some cases, reduce Datadog bills by over 50%. These competitors are typically grounded in technologies such as Prometheus (open source systems monitoring originally built at SoundCloud).

Chronosphere: Palo Alto announced its plans to acquire Chronosphere in December n 2025, the deal is expected to close in 1H26. Chronosphere is growing at over 100% at $160mn of ARR. Industry feedback suggests that Chronosphere is gaining share because of its strong controls on metrics cardinality, such that customers can realize signi fi cant savings on their observability bills. Chronosphere was founded in 2019 with a team of engineers from Uber. Grafana: Grafana was last valued at over $6bn, per its August 2025 press release. At n the time, it announced over >$250mn in ARR; in September 2025, it announced over $400mn in ARR, implying a ~50% yoy growth rate. Grafana is typically coupled with 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

an open source stack and does particularly well at mid market accounts that do not need the extra functionality that a best of breed solution like Datadog provides. Relative to Datadog, Grafana's user interface is weaker by requiring more expertise and manual work; if customers are willing to accept a more fragmented set of observability tools (and higher management cost as a result), total observability cost goes down. - Clickhouse -based observability: customers can choose to build their own n observability stacks, built on Clickhouse or other columnar databases. These solutions are orders of magnitude cheaper for log storage and querying, and process high-cardinality traces and events data at much lower cost.

Source: Gartner

Her fi ndahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) analysis Source: Gartner, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research We see three additional medium-term risks: Our conversations at AWS Reinvent in December 2025 suggest that AWS is more n intensely focused on capturing observability share of wallet Snow fl ake announced plans to acquire Observe on 1/8 n CrowdStrike may choose to enter the observability market more aggressively over n the next 3 years, as has all the pieces and a particularly powerful agent to be able to deliver high performance observability tools. Its back end is built on Humio, which was founded in 2016 and acquired in 2021. Our industry conversations suggest that EDR agents have historically been optimized for performance and observability 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 agents have historically been optimized for minimal overhead; CrowdStrike solves for both with its proprietary fi ltering technology that is both high performance and carries minimal compute overhead.

Datadog underperformed through part of 2025 primarily due to investor concern that OpenAI may reduce its level of spend. The concern surfaced in part due to a Clickhouse blog post in June 2025 that detailed a case study with OpenAI, which suggested that OpenAI could increasingly insource observability/monitoring or shift workloads to home-grown tooling, which would reduce its reliance on Datadog. There are also a number of open roles at OpenAI for building observability products. This was against a backdrop of large scale customers such as the hyperscalers having brought observability in house as their businesses scaled, and select instances of large customer churn like Shopify. At the same time, the quality of revenue tied to OpenAI can also be viewed to be lower quality: OpenAI's consumption is tied to AI-native workloads that are inherently bursty (e.g. model-training cycles, rapid scaling during new releases). This usage pattern is more exposed to cost-optimization cycles, similar to the broader observability pullback seen in 2022-2023.

Datadog's OpenAI revenue is a function of a committed minimum and overage in excess of this minimum. This is true for any Datadog customer, and we believe that the typical mix could be close to 85%/15% committed vs. overage, based on management comments. We believe the mix for OpenAI over the last 12 months was higher than the average customer's % overage given the pace at which OpenAI was growing. Datadog has noted that it renewed its contract with its largest customer at better unit economics in 4Q25, and it gave this customer better economics, consistent with any customer who chooses to buy from Datadog in larger scale. While Datadog has not commented about OpenAI speci fi cally, we believe the total $ amount from OpenAI to Datadog that is committed will likely go up in 2026, but this does not give us insight into the % of revenue that is beyond the committed minimum. Importantly, we believe that Datadog will guide based on the trajectory of OpenAI's current usage with an bu ff er for conservatism based on its historical guidance philosophy. This is a key factor in shaping our scenarios for

bear, base, and bull cases in 2026 (summarized below). 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Estimated Datadog AI-native ARR (LHS) vs. % of total ARR (RHS) Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We introduce a 12-month price target of $113 (14% downside vs. 21% upside on average across our coverage), based on 30x our SNTM uFCF estimate. Our target multiple of 30x is toward the low end of Datadog's infrastructure and security peers and a ~20% discount to the NTM median of ~37x. We believe a 20% discount is appropriate given the fragmented nature of the observability space that lends itself to more competition, and our view that competition is likely to be elevated over the next several quarters (and potentially years). For example, Zscaler trades at 30x 2027 FCF with similar growth (~20%) and margins (high 20s) to Datadog, with the primary delta vs. Datadog's multiple today being more mature competition in our view.

We assume coverage of Intuit (INTU) with a Neutral rating (from Buy) and 10% upside to our 12-month price target of $720. We are constructive on Intuit's AI strategy: its GenOS platform allows SMBs to build unique custom work fl ows to marry horizontal and vertical functionality, SMBs are least likely to turn to custom software builds for AI, and AI should drive productivity gains in use cases like tax and accounting because these work fl ow outputs are veri fi able. There are two dynamics that keep us neutral: 1) Intuit's execution in tax from season to season have been inconsistent. Our analysis suggests that Intuit has lost share in the DIY tax segment while it has been focused on converting its existing DIY users to its Assisted o ff ering; Intuit is now in an investment cycle for performance marketing and brick and mortar to compete more squarely with competition. Intuit's share loss has moderated in

2025 and we look to gauge whether this cycle's investments can drive better user growth or better mix shift. 2) We estimate that Intuit has about 20% exposure to the rates cycle via its Quick Books Capital and Credit Karma segments. We have limited visibility into the durability of growth in these two segments and believe fundamentals may fl uctuate with the rates cycle.

- 1. We are constructive on Intuit applying AI to its GBS segment We believe Intuit has increased its pace of product innovation to intersect the AI opportunity, with more recent updates including deepening product functionality with GenOS for low-code bespoke work fl ows and for the mid market, and an 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

improved turnaround plan for Mailchimp. Intuit's GBS segment consists primarily of QuickBooks, its accounting/payroll/payments tool for SMBs, and its Mailchimp acquisition for marketing (acquired in 2021 for $12bn). Intuit discloses two segments of QuickBooks: QuickBooks Online (22% of revenue, growing at 24%) QuickBooks Desktop (8%, growing 6%). Intuit also discloses Online Services, which includes Mailchimp (6%, growing 3%), Payroll (8%, growing 27%) and Money for Businesses (9%, growing 25%). We highlight the following key drivers for each GBS' segment:

Pricing & AI: Growth is a function of subscriber growth and pricing, which is the n bigger contributor to growth in any given year and also fl uctuates more. Subscriber growth is in the mid single digits given this product was originally launched in 2001; while we were unable to fi nd good correlations with macro indicators, subscriber growth does seem to track with the general health of the SMB ecosystem. On pricing, Intuit has been thoughtful about the timing and magnitude of pricing increases, including a 9%/15%/16% increase for Simple Start/Essentials/Plus announced mid 2025, which resulted in a step-up 1Q. Our industry pricing work suggests that driving productivity gains via AI will be key to the next phase of pricing power. For example, Intuit cites that its accounting agent saves users 12 hours per month, on average, with each of these hours being valued at $75. We estimate that this product could drive $900 of value per month, and if Intuit captures 10% of this

value, it would equate to a $90 increase in ARPU (compared to a base seat value of $52). Independent of SKU-speci fi c pricing increases, Intuit also bene fi ts from mix shift up towards higher tiers and from new customers coming onto higher tiers.

GenOS positions Intuit to expand into vertical-speci fi c work fl ows. Intuit formally n launched GenOS in 2023 post several quarters of streamlining its back end infrastructure. GenOS is the foundation for Intuit's AI-powered tools; it includes a dedicated AI development environment (GenStudio) and UX framework (GenUX) and leverages leading LLMs. The goal is to more quickly develop and iterate on new features. We view GenOS as a way for Intuit to leverage its existing horizontal applications into more custom and bespoke work fl ows - not to the extent where they encroach on vertical-speci fi c providers like ServiceTitan, but in a way that enables its existing customer base to derive more value from the platform. At the 2025 Investor Day, Intuit outlined $25bn+ TAM across four key verticals: Construction, Professional Services, Wholesale & Manufacturing, and Non-Pro fi t. The idea is to use agentic AI to automate traditional industry work fl ows using industry

domain-speci fi c knowledge, to create products like bidding tools, inventory management, project management, and industry-speci fi c fi nancial analysis which it historically would not have been able to o ff er pro fi tably. Upmarket strategy: Intuit has improved its product and go to market positioning n for the enterprise, and discloses mid market datapoints that include QBO Advanced (its premium SKU, ~5% of subscribers) and Intuit Enterprise Services (IES, we estimate ~$100mn - see Exhibit). Contract value is $27K on average, compared to $1.2K for the broader QBO segment. Consistent with other SMB-focused software companies, coming up market is an evolution, and we believe Intuit has iterated on 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

its strategy several times since they launched Advanced in 2018. We believe the near term potential is in the cohort of QBO customers who are on small business SKU but have the pro fi le of a mid market business; there is a 2x uplift when a business with multiple licenses consolidates them into one IES subscription. Although convincing a mid-market business to spend twice as much with Intuit will take selling, Intuit cites 300% ROI over 3 years with IES, with $30-50k saved vs a traditional ERP implementation. On go to market, Intuit reorganized its mid-market sales force in 2024, with a coverage salesperson and domain expert assigned to each account (domain experts also facilitate cross sell).

Source: SimilarWeb, Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Exhibit 52: If Intuit can broadly roll out AI-powered features with a demonstrable value-add, they should be able to maintain pricing power in the near-term

Mailchimp turnaround key. Mailchimp was acquired in September 2021 for $12bn, and has been the most challenged part of Intuit's business, having decelerated from 15% to

We source historical list prices from the following sources: Demian & Co; Insightful Accountant; CPA Practice Advisor; Haynie & Co CPAs; Soukup & Bush; Kemper Group. Source: Company fi lings, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

2% in FY25 (120bps drag to Intuit's FY25 revenue growth). FY25 net new revenue growth was negative despite Intuit exercising pricing levers, implying customer churn more than o ff set the tailwind from pricing. We believe the pace of innovation and competition in marketing technology has been high, with newer technologies like Klaviyo bene fi ting from a preferred status in the Shopify ecosystem. We outline Mailchimp's key challenges in Exhibit 53 - the turnaround plan includes balancing low end and high end functionality, scaling the go to market support teams, and focusing on mid market adoption where product/market/ fi t is better. Taken together with our broader industry work, our Mailchimp estimates are below the Street; but we view this as a less strategic part of the growth algorithm.

Payroll: positive leading indicators, long runway (8% of the business, growing 25% in FY25). We believe Payroll growth is sustainable given its level of underpenetration relative to Intuit's installed base, at 7% of the QuickBook base. At the 2025 Investor Day, management noted 18mm US workers were paid annually via QB Payroll, and that payroll penetration is 12pp higher for mid-market (which in turn is the faster growing cohort in QB at +40%). Simplistically, we see upside scenarios where the Payroll business becomes 3x to 7x bigger, with the low end based on Payroll approaching the size of the QBO business, and the high end based on Payroll penetration approaching QBO penetration (note the higher price point as revenue per MAU is ~$1000 vs. QBO at $439). Leveraging data from GS Data Works, we show App Downloads (79% correlated with MAUs on a 2-month lag) have been accelerating, and MAUs are 91% correlated

to QBO sub growth., leading us to believe that the payroll business is a key driver for QBO sub growth. There isn't enough of a history to correlate Workforce Management MAUs with Payroll revenue growth, but logically it should be related, and based on MAUs accelerating in during FY25 and the business accelerating from FY24 to FY25, a directional relationship is likely. MAUs have continued to accelerate to 40% y/y, which would imply user counts could actually accelerate medium term, though we do not model this in our base case. Directionally, MAUs accelerated in FY25 and revenue accelerated into FY25. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 Money for Businesses: similar to Payroll, Intuit classi fi es Money for Business within Online Services with minimal additional disclosures. There are two main subcomponents: Payments and QuickBooks Capital.

The payments business includes their GoPayment app (used at POS in conjunction with a card reader), receipt generation, transaction recording/matching into quickbooks, and automated payments. Based on our math, the bulk of the revenue generation is based on transaction volumes; we model volume (disclosed at their two most recent Analyst Days) multiplied by a net interchange fee of ~55bps (on our math). QuickBooks Capital generates revenue via net interest on the loans it holds and realized gains when it sells loans. Their loan volume was $3.6bn last year implying ~14% take rate. Given the limited disclosures for this line item it is di ffi cult to reconstruct a history. The total size of the US small business fi nancing market is ~$550bn/yr, implying very small penetration currently and room for future growth.

Source: SensorTower, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Intuit's Consumer business includes TurboTax (64%), Credit Karma (28%) and ProTax (8%). Intuit's consumer strategy is centered on a year-round 'system of intelligence' for consumers to manage their personal fi nance. The segment has grown at a 10% 10-year CAGR vs. GBS at 18%. Similar to the GBS segment, Consumer bene fi ts from large TAMs, complementary products that can be cross-sold, and a wealth of historical data that can be used to train AI models. We look to gauge to what extent Intuit can drive another year of good execution (e.g. better mix and share) through the tax season.

TurboTax: Stabilization of share trends and return on 2026 investment will be key We believe the key debate is to what extent Intuit is able to accelerate share gains into the Assisted market (where tax professionals assist consumers) because of AI functionality, and protect themselves from de fl ationary risk in the DIY market (where consumers do their taxes themselves). We believe applying AI to drive software share vs. labor in the assisted tax market is a very compelling use case, in part because of Intuit's existing credibility with a younger generation of fi lers, market share data already suggesting they are gaining share in assisted, and because the outputs are tightly bound and demonstrably veri fi able. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

The bear case centers on foundation models replicating domain expertise (tax prep, the tax code, audits, etc.) to complete taxes better than traditional rules-based programming, creating new competition in the assisted and DIY tax cohorts. Furthermore, a foundation model company could make their own AI tax solution accessible to their existing consumer base, where they already have strong distribution. As in other areas of application software, the ultimate equilibrium point of how AI shapes the app layer remains ucnlear. Nonetheless, we o ff er the following context:

Price: Investors see a risk with AI native products being able to o ff er solutions at n much lower price. In tax, free and low cost DIY alternatives have existed for years, and consumers continue to use assisted alternatives even though they cost more. On features , Intuit is itself using AI to improve their tax o ff ering to make tax a n 'done-for-you' experience, similar to the way it saves QuickBooks users time on accounting. AI-native startups would therefore need to replicate Intuit's existing domain strengths to achieve feature parity. Risk: Even if AI could potentially match convenience and price, consumers would n need to be sure that the risk of hallucinations and mistakes is truly minimal, and that downside risks (missing out on a refund, being audited) are compensated for via a guarantee.

Intuit's recent announcement with OpenAI ($100mn+ multi-year contract to n license OAI's models within GenOS and provide access to Intuit apps in ChatGPT) also protect them from de fl ation risk. The OpenAI deal will also enable ChatGPT's 100m+ users to access QuickBooks, Mailchimp, and Credit Karma. Though Intuit will be reaching customers through ChatGPT, customer data and the work fl ows will remain with Intuit. For example, a tax question can be asked through the ChatGPT interface, but the customer will be shown links to TurboTax's online fi ling website/local expert. Intuit has stated their preference for being agnostic about what channels they use to reach customers, so we view this partnership as similar to customer acquisition via Google Search. We see a scenario where AI-engine optimiziation lowers CAC vs. SEO.

2025 marked a shift in Intuit's execution in its tax business, post a disappointing 2022-2024. According to Intuit, 11 mn taxpayers who use assisted tax solutions (~13% of the total) switch their provider each year. A 2025 survey of 2,000 taxpayers by Talker Research (link) found that of the 63% who fi le their own taxes, more than half said they would consider hiring a tax professional within the next two years. The survey found younger respondents and those with more than one source of income are likelier to hire a tax preparer. Taken together, this means that the share opportunity grows over time as the Gen Z/gig worker cohorts become a larger share of US tax payers. We see the following factors as key to Intuit consistently surprising to the upside:

- Improving top-of-funnel marketing: Intuit has noted before that once a customer 1. is in the funnel, and is engaged with the right expert, there is an 82% conversion rate. The bigger variable has been at the top of the funnel. For example, 30% of assisted customers decide how they will get their taxes done before December 25th, and Intuit this year pulled forward advertising to earlier in the season. Similarly, TurboTax was not showing up in the 6mm Google searches for 'Tax professional near me', 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

despite the fact that >80% of US fi lers live within 10 miles of a TurboTax Pro. Filers are 5x more likely to covert when given a local option. Third, they were not su ffi ciently integrating Credit Karma with TurboTax, and enabled zero-click login for 70% of CK members (vs. 5% in 2024) which drove improved cross-sell (1pp contribution). Finally, Intuit said that they realized they had a brand awareness problem with consumers often associating them with DIY rather than assisted. They are gearing their marketing at fi xing that gap. There is more room for improvement on each factor as Intuit's marketing strategies and data analytics are further honed, and as brand awareness builds.

- Going on the o ff ense in DIY: Intuit lost share in DIY partly because H&R Block (HRB, n covered by George Tong) leaned more aggressively into paid search during the 2024 tax season. HRB noted on their 3Q24 call that paid volumes in the 2024 tax season grew 6%, and said that many of these fi lers were from TurboTax. Starting with the 2025 tax season, Intuit implemented GTM changes for DIY just as HRB became more deliberate with its marketing spend, driving share gains for Intuit (link). Another reason for the share losses in DIY was mis-execution. At their 2024 Investor Day, management noted they lost 1.6M low-income customers, due to an experience/value mismatch with a sizable price gap between Free and Deluxe o ff erings and confusing fi ling experience. With the kinks in the o ff ering worked out, pricing strategy better aligned, their closest competitor reducing focus on the low-ARPR channels, and the

IRS Direct File program e ff ectively shut down, DIY may see the right conditions to return to growth.

Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research Exhibit 56: HRB took share of MAUs and downloads during a marketing push ahead of the 2024 tax season; during and since the 2025 tax season TurboTax has outperformed Source: Sensor Tower, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research, SimilarWeb

A few notes on mix: Part of the decline in DIY returns was normalization from COVID, when the volume of DIY fi lers increased related to stimulus checks. But part has been a deliberate move to drive growth for assisted returns which average 2.2x the revenue per return (ARPR). While industry mix has been stable over the last 3 years, TurboTax has increased assisted mix from <10% in FY19 to 21% in FY25. Ideally, TurboTax should be able to grow in both Assisted and DIY, as DIY may be a funnel for assisted. But even if the transition was 100% cannibalistic, and TurboTax e ff ectively shifted customers from DIY to Assisted on a 1-for-1 basis, this would still be accretive to revenues. We estimate that each 1pp of market share transfer from DIY to assisted equates to ~$125mn of revenue. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

However, if TurboTax is unable to back fi ll the top of the funnel and loses 'organic' share in DIY, this may impact long-term fundamentals. For every one assisted return TurboTax wins, they can lose at most 2.2 DIY returns. Based on our estimates, this occurred during FY22 and FY24 (See Exhibit 57) where Intuit saw ~$25mn/65bps mix headwinds to revenue in those years, but was able to realize 14% price (unit-weighted) in FY22 and 9% price in FY24. This trade-o ff has been getting better, with TurboTax able to grow Assisted returns by 700K last year while sacri fi cing 'only' 1.7MM returns - a 1.6x ratio which is accretive. We expect continued improvement into FY26, though this will require execution on GTM changes, as discussed previously. As we show in Exhibit 59, if all parts

of the model (mix, like-for-like price, and market share) all pull in the same direction, this can create signi fi cant upside for TurboTax. In an upside scenario with zero cannibalization (which we do not model in our base case), the segment would grow 15%, which would be the fastest growth since FY18.

Intuit acquired Credit Karma for $8.1bn in 2020, implying a 15x NTM EBIT multiple, or e ff ectively 8.5x FY25 EBIT. Many investors view Credit Karma as a low quality asset that primarily monetizes lead generation into fi nancial providers (credit cards, mortgages). We agree that the technical moat is lower and the business is more cyclical, with EBIT declining 22% from FY22 to FY24. However, the technology may be more di ff erentiated than investors appreciate. For example, the Lightbox engine gives lenders access to thousands of de-identi fi ed data points to allow lenders to make real-time, pre-approved credit o ff ers to Credit Karma members. Based on the company's disclosures, we calculate that CK's Credit Card/Personal Loan/Auto Insurance businesses grew 26%/45%/27% in FY25, which likely re fl ected some normalization from more stable interest rates/recovery o ff a weak 2023, but also re fl ects market share gains. The

more users Intuit is able to add to their ecosystem, the more useful their algorithms get. We also expect strong results in the near term given Credit Karma's strong correlations with our SMB tracker.

We introduce a 12 month price target of $720 (11% upside) applying a 27x multiple on our SNTM (Q5-Q8) EPS estimate. We consider a comp group of scaled application software peers. This comp group trades at 26x NTM EPS and 27.6x NTM FCF, with a median of 15% revenue growth and 17% EPS growth (NTM). Intuit o ff ers 15% revenue growth and 15% EPS growth; we believe the size of the TAM and the technology moat justify a multiple in line with the group despite ~10% lower EPS growth. Investors have typically been rewarded for buying the stock on pullbacks (e.g. a bad tax season, a poorly received acquisition, macro concerns), but the stock is +6% since the beginning of 2025 vs. application peers down 16% to 48%. On a 12 month time frame rolling forward in weekly increments, Intuit has historically outperformed the NDX 58% of the time, with particular out-performance during the dotcom bubble, through the GFC, in 2017-19, and during the rally o ff

the COVID bottom. Since 1990, Intuit has outperformed the NDX 79% of the time when the NDX is negative, but only outperforms 57% of the time when the NDX returns positive. This illustrates that Intuit has historically outperformed during both upswings and downturns, but is especially defensible in a downturn. Since the beginning of 2025, Intuit's NTM P/E multiple has compressed only 5% vs. the peer average of -17% (CRM -31% and WDAY -23%). 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

GS DataWorks analysis provided by Dan Duggan, Ph.D. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We assume coverage on Oracle at Buy (from Neutral) with 27% upside to our 12 month price target of $240. We are positive on Oracle's technology advantage in AI compute workloads, and believe the company has the potential to gain share vs. the cloud cycle (backlog suggests ~25% share of new cloud revenue in 3 years from <10% today). The question then becomes the timing and unit economics associated with the capex build to support backlog being recognized as revenue. We are tactically positive on the stock as we believe visibility will improve over the next 12 months: 1) we expect revenue reacceleration over the course of this year as more tranches of the 1.2 GW Abilene data center come online; 2) we expect gross pro fi t to trough in the next 12 months, followed by meaningful acceleration, based on our bottom up build of fi xed and variable COGS; 3) we believe we are close to peak debt raises, as our build suggests Oracle can execute on its data center build with less than $80mn in debt raised

(consistent with management comments of <$100bn), of which $18bn has already been raised and a further $38bn is already anticipated. For Oracle to be an investment rather than a trade, we look to better gauge the sustainability of growth and pricing beyond 2030, as well as in its database and apps businesses (~30% of sales). At $190, we believe the market is already discounting Oracle/Street forecasts of $20 in FY30 in EPS, and we see a scenario where gross margin is below the Street this year ahead of acceleration. As such, we approach risk/reward for the stock by considering bear/base/bull scenarios that discounts OpenAI commitments by 100%/30%/0% to arrive at $10/$15/$25 of EPS or a 4:1 upside/downside skew when applying a 10x-25x range of P/E multiples.

Compute capacity turning on in OCI is likely to drive accelerating OCI revenue; 1. gross pro fi t growth is likely to trough in the next 12 months. Oracle's capex was up 200%+ in FY25 (ended May 2025) and is on track to be up 140%+ in FY26. While we do not have the exact mix between long-dated non-kit related assets (tied to data center land/power/cooling) and short-dated kit related assets (tied directly to compute and therefore revenue), we estimate that growth in kit is accelerating through the fi scal year. This likely translates to accelerating OCI revenue growth in CY26. While we believe this dynamic is somewhat understood (for example, Oracle raised FY26E capex by $15bn in its December earnings report and raised its FY27E revenue outlook by $4bn), we believe it is has been somewhat o ff set by mixed execution in any given quarter (e.g. Oracle missing in-quarter OCI revenue estimates but maintaining or raising its medium-term forecast). While we do not take

a view on any given quarter and we expect data center delays will continue to create headline risk, we expect the market to react favorably to backlog converting to revenue growth. Customer exposure is likely to be diversi fi ed: Existing AI OCI customers include: 2. OpenAI, Neospace, X AI, SoundHound AI, Suno, Luma AI, baseten, LiveKit, character.ai, and Modal. We expect continued customer diversi fi cation as the industry remains supply constrained and because OCI's wins with sophisticated technology customers such as OpenAI, X and Meta credentialize it in the frontier model space and in the enterprise. OCI has made several architectural decisions that 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

help it benchmark near the top of industry analysis (e.g. SemiAnalysis), which we detail below. Given the compute-intensity of training large models, microseconds of latency or percentages of bandwidth loss compound. OCI's fl at network, RoCE interconnect, and SmartNIC isolation work to deliver throughput, predictability, and linear scalability required by large-scale AI workloads. SemiAnalysis estimates that Oracle's optimized networking con fi guration enables up to a 20% capex advantage vs. neoclouds and a 5-10% capex advantage vs. hyperscalers.

We are likely close to peak debt raises: Capex in FY26E is $50bn and our model 3. contemplates total capex of $340bn (with no BYOC, FY25-FY30) - we estimate capex peaking in FY29 in accordance with the more material revenue ramp. While capex will continue to go up, we expect as capacity comes online and revenue ramps more materially Oracle will increasingly fund its capex organically, and thus debt raises are likely peaking. Our bull case model assumes total debt raised of ~$70bn, of which $18bn has been announced and another $38bn is being planned. Once we are through these tranches (which arguably are already expected by investors), we believe the pace of debt raises will go down.

BYOC puts and takes: Oracle has discussed fi nancing its growth through customers 4. bringing their own chips to be installed in Oracle data centers, which would reduce Oracle's upfront capex. We see several puts and takes to fi nancials in this business model: on the one hand, distributing the upfront investment risk back to the customer reduces pricing power and thus gross margins; on the other hand, GPU procurement is not necessarily a di ff erentiated business model (hardware resellers typically capture 10-20% gross margin). Our expert conversations suggest that BYOC is only likely to happen selectively (conversations with 10+ experts suggest '2' on a fi ve point scale of likelihood e.g. because of the challenges with SLAs); regardless, we would see any announcements as a positive for Oracle.

Value in the stack beyond infrastructure: The most durable software platforms will 5. need vectors to deliver value beyond the infrastructure layer as the AI ecosystem matures. Management forecasts OCI to be 75% of company revenue in 2030 and OCI will generate more pro fi t as it matures; however, we believe Oracle can deliver value at the platform and application layer as well: Database: Oracle's opportunity with its AI database and data platform is a. substantial, driven by its unique position as the custodian of enterprise data combined with strategic AI capabilities. Oracle remains a dominant player as a custodian of enterprise data, albeit at a lower market share (~15% in 2024 vs. ~40% in 2014). The Oracle AI Database 26ai architects AI into the core of data management, with Oracle AI Vector Search enabling customers to securely combine search for documents, images, and other unstructured data with search on private business data without moving or duplicating it. Oracle projects $20bn in AI Database and Data Platform revenues in FY30, a 50%+ CAGR from FY25.

Strategic SaaS: Oracle's SaaS o ff erings form an integrated suite of cloud b. applications designed for enterprise back-o ffi ce functions, including Oracle Fusion Cloud ERP, HCM, EPM, and SCM. These applications share a common 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

data model that spans across core business applications, enabling customers to extract more business value from their adoption of multiple SaaS o ff erings. Oracle's success in the ERP market stems from its platform approach, strategic cloud migration advantages, and strong market positioning as one of the top three ERP providers globally. The company has leveraged its database legacy, acquisition strategy, and multi-product ecosystem to maintain competitive advantages in both mid-market and enterprise segments. Oracle is developing suites of integrated AI agent-based applications for ERP, EPM, supply chain, manufacturing, human resources, customer engagement, plus industry applications for healthcare, banking, utilities, retail, hospitality, and many other industries - we believe Oracle can leverage its incumbent SaaS customer base to drive increased adoption of its AI agents.

Oracle revenue GSe/other companies FactSet consensus estimates Source: FactSet, Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research - 1. OCI is gaining share and its tech di ff erentiation makes this durable at least over the next 12 months

Oracle's cloud infrastructure business (OCI) is entering a period of hyper-growth fueled by the AI compute cycle, which we believe is in part driven by early technical choices in architecture. Oracle entered the cloud computing market in 2016, several years after rival hyperscalers (AWS in 2006, GCP in 2008, and Azure in 2010). While previously focused on expanding its enterprise software dominance, when cloud computing began to accelerate in the early 2010s Oracle recognized the opportunity in Platform as a Service (PaaS) and Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) tied to cloud computing. Despite being a late entrant, Oracle initially attracted customers by leveraging its expertise in databases, ERP systems, and enterprise application management to build a cloud to handle these complex applications. In 2023, OCI was $5.7bn in revenue vs. AWS at $91bn, Azure at $47bn, and GCP at $33bn - re fl ecting share gains, but from a smaller base.

With the boom of AI training workloads, OCI has hit an in fl ection point as the requirements of large-scale AI training align with OCI's existing architectural advantages. While Oracle's late entry into cloud computing was initially a competitive Exhibit 64: With gross pro fi t projected to ramp more materially in FY28-FY30 after a trough in the next 12 months Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

disadvantage, it also enabled Oracle to re fi ne OCI's architecture after observing the architectural and pricing limitations of existing hyperscalers: Oracle's earlier database technological advancements in fl uenced how it approached the OCI buildout. Oracle pioneered real application clusters (RAC) in the early 2000s to scale its database architecture. While traditional databases could only run on a single server (limiting performance and up time to that machine's capacity), RAC enabled multiple database instances to run on separate servers while sharing a single database, connected through a high-speed interconnect. This required Oracle to develop low-latency interconnects, remote direct memory access (RDMA) communication, and shared-storage architectures years before the cloud era - when Oracle later built OCI, it embedded these same principles into its foundation.

Also notable in Oracle's foundation is its 2009 acquisition of Sun Microsystems ($7.4bn), which gave it system-level engineering expertise across servers, CPUs, storage, networking, and operation systems. Sun was one of the earliest commercial adopters of In fi niBand: an implementation of RDMA as a high-throughput, low-latency interconnect technology used in HPC clusters and supercomputers. Oracle used this expertise in its Exadata database platform, using In fi niBand for ultra fast node-to-node database communication. This also informed OCI's use of RDMA over Converged Ethernet (RoCE), a modern, cloud-scale In fi ni-Band, when building its network fabric. Oracle was the fi rst major cloud provider to make RDMA standard across its infrastructure (rather than an HPC add-on).

Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

| Tr ad i t i o n a l                                                                                                                                      | Hyp e r sca l e r                                                                                                                                                                                               | OC I                                                                                                                                                                                      | AI Appli ca bili t y          |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| ·Three-tier networks to support north to south traffic                                                                                                   | ·Flat, non-blocking Clos topology supporting low east-west latency                                                                                                                                              | ·AI workloads require massive inter-node communication ·OCI's architecture ensures each server has an equal-cost, high-bandwidth path to other nodes without oversubscription             | N et w o rk D es i g n        |
| ·Bolted RDMA onto subsets of their fleets (AWS Elastic Fabric Adapter, Azure's InfiniBand for select HPC SKUs, Google's TPU pods)                        | · Designed around native RDMA over Converged Ethernet (RoCE) fabric, which spans its entire data center network giving each compute node access to ultra-low- latency, high-throughput communication by default | ·ROCE v2 fabric enables direct memory-to- memory communication between GPUs across nodes by passing the CPU and kernel entirely · Reduces latency and boosts effective bandwidth per node | RDMA o v e r R oC E F a bri c |
| ·VMs networked within a software-defined network - hypervisor and control plane share the server, processor, and storage resources with the customer VMs | · Developed a custom offload architecture in which the network virtualization runs on separate, dedicated hardware (a SmartNIC) that fully isolates tenants                                                     | ·GPUs and CPUs can use 100% of their cycles for training, while the SmartNIC handles networking and security functions independently.                                                     | Vir t u a liz at i o n        |

- Flat network design: OCI's fl at Clos network eliminates the traditional three-tiered n hierarchy in which east-west tra ffi c between nodes often hit bottlenecks, especial for HPC or AI workloads that require massive inter-node communication. OCI's 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 architecture ensures each GPU server has an equal-cost, high-bandwidth path to every other node, with no oversubscription and minimal hop count. This enables uniform communication latency across an AI cluster, allowing large training jobs to scale linearly.

RDMA over Converged Ethernet (RoCE) Fabric: OCI's RoCEv2 fabric enables direct n memory-to-memory communication between GPUs across nodes by passing the CPU and kernel entirely. This reduces latency and boosts e ff ective bandwidth per node. Hardware-level network virtualization: OCI's o ff -box design means GPUs and n CPUs can use 100% of their cycles for training, while the SmartNIC handles networking and security functions independently.

Given the compute-intensity of training large models, microseconds of latency or percentages of bandwidth loss compound. OCI's fl at network, RoCE interconnect, and SmartNIC isolation work to deliver throughput, predictability, and linear scalability required by large-scale AI workloads. SemiAnalysis estimates that Oracle's optimized networking con fi guration enables up to a 20% capex advantage vs. neoclouds and a 5-10% capex advantage vs. hyperscalers. Oracle continues to invest in its architecture to optimize for AI workloads - at AI World in October, Oracle debuted its OCI Zettascale 10 supercluster, which delivers 16 zettaFLOPS within a multigigawatt cluster, spanning multiple data centers and integrating as many as 800k NVIDIA GPUs. These are tied together via Oracle's Acceleron RoCE network fabric, which uses specialized Ethernet NICs and cables to link GPUs within an OCI data center.

With the Acceleron network fabric, customers can leverage large AI clusters by connecting GPU NICs to multiple network switches simultaneously, thereby creating a fl atter network fabric with many isolated network planes, resulting in 2x the potential networking capacity, up to 2x the storage IOPS (input/output per second), and zero-trust packet routing security policies enforced directly at the host.

Source: Company data, Visible Alpha Consensus Data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research - 2. Modeling out the data center build: solving for revenue via capex; solving for capex via debt Oracle announced a $300bn deal with OpenAI in August 2025, and provided an initial forecast for OCI to achieve $144bn in FY2030 revenue. This includes revenue tied to AI and classic cloud, as well as hosted database revenue. At its analyst day in 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

October, Oracle updated its forecasts to re fl ect an incremental $60bn in new deals signed between August and October, from four separate customers. Oracle's disclosed AI customers include Meta, X.ai, Neospace, SoundHound AI, and several others, as well as OpenAI. Oracle currently forecasts $166bn in OCI revenue in FY2030 , a 75% 5-year CAGR and OCI at 75% of total company revenue (vs. ~20% today). Supporting these targets, Oracle's RPO as of 2QFY26 was >$500bn, with ~$300bn tied to OpenAI.

To help inform our model forecasts and verify Oracle's target 30-40% gross margin over a 6 year contract lifetime, we build a detailed plan of capex and P&L costs. Our forecasts are based on our industry work across sectors, including conversations and analysis reconciliations with the GS Semis and Data Center teams. Our estimates are intended to be a starting point given the overall lack of visibility into Oracle speci fi c metrics.

- We start with Oracle's OCI forecast to arrive at implied net new revenue for FY26 1. through FY30. We split net new revenue into: a) Non AI net new revenue, which is 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 further split between i) database net new based on Oracle's long-term targets and ii) core OCI net new assuming 10% yoy growth; and b) AI net new revenue, which we back into based on total net new and non AI net new.

Next, we forecast capex on kit (GPUs, other compute, networking). We assume that 2. kit related capex (GPUs, CPUs, networking, storage) will be procured about 3 months before it comes online, recognizing that Oracle is taking steps to shorten this timeline and that it could be as low as a couple weeks. We drive our kit forecast o ff net new AI revenue. We assume the ratio of kit to net new AI revenue is 2.5x, based on CoreWeave's metrics, improving to 2x by FY28. Recall that CoreWeave's revenue yield on net fi xed assets is 40%. This capex estimate also informs our depreciation forecast. We assume that capex recurs every 6 years given a 6 year GPU useful life.

We model non kit related capex (land, power, cooling) based on the details Oracle 3. and its partners have already provided about its Stargate facilities. To date, disclosed costs suggest $14.50-$16.65 mn per megawatt of commissioned IT load, which compares to the industry average of $7-12 for classic data centers and up to $20 for AI datacenters. The annual cost to Oracle will be the cost of leasing and the variable cost of maintaining and operating the facilities; we assume 22% (12% from leasing and 10% from variable costs). Our 10% variable cost estimate back solves based on Oracle's gross margin disclosure and its kit to non kit disclosure (kit makes up 65% of total cost), and also reconciles with industry commentary and CoreWeave's disclosures.

We then forecast EBITDA and operating cash fl ow based on Oracle's historical 4. margins. We assume $10bn in cash is held on the balance sheet as a bu ff er (equivalent to about 2 quarters of opex). For the purpose of this analysis, we assume that any capex that cannot be funded by operating cash fl ow is funded by debt. We then estimate the cost of debt based on conversations with our Credit Strategy team (supported by analysis on typical cost of debt for software companies). Below we summarize what we know about Oracle's fi rst 5 data center sites, as well as the potential for Site 6, as well as our estimates for the timing on when non-kit related capex (land, building, power and cooling) is spent.

|----------------------------------|-------------------|-----------------------|-------|--------------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|

- There is enough information to verify that Oracle's gross margin target of 30-40% 1. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 over a 6-year contract lifetime is reasonable. The Abilene data center provides revenue coverage for Oracle's revenue forecast 2. through FY26 and part of FY27. Wisconsin provides additional coverage through FY27. Other Stargate projects including Shakleford and Santa Ana provide coverage through 2030. Oracle's net debt to EBITDA leverage peaks at <4x in FY26 or FY27 (excluding 3. operating leases). Taking our FY24-FY30 forecast in isolation (i.e. making no assumptions about FY31), Oracle would exit FY29 at 1.6x net debt to leverage. These ratios are well within investment grade based on agency baselines.

We estimate that 50%+ of Oracle's 2030 targeted revenue is tied to OpenAI, along with the vast majority of its datacenter commitments to be able to ultimately deliver capacity and recognize revenue. For illustrative purposes, we consider a scenario in which OpenAI's contracts are either more fl exible than a typical contract (i.e. revenues are achieved over a longer duration), or the resulting revenues are lower than expected. In this case, Oracle would still have to account for its own fi nancial obligations and fi xed costs: Long term leases for the 5 Stargate facilities: by our estimates, at a 12% annual cost n this would be ~$11bn in fi xed costs by FY29 The remaining term of the 6-year GPUs for any existing capacity that was allocated n toward OpenAI

Hypothetically, in a scenario where revenue from OpenAI goes to zero in a 2028 time-frame, we assume the costs tied to long term leases and existing depreciation GPU are fi xed, and that Oracle can somewhat grow into its GPU footprint with other customers (as OpenAI demand gets redistributed to other LLMs), but that this will take time. In this scenario, we expect Oracle's net debt to EBITDA ratio to go from ~3.5x in our base case (where OpenAI is discounted 30%) to 4x. We estimate Oracle would earn ~$10 in 2030 EPS in this scenario, growing EPS at an 10% CAGR from FY25. Applying a 15x P/E multiple and discounting back by 2.5 years (to be consistent with our SNTM framework) would imply ~35% downside to the current stock price. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Oracle is shifting to a more capital intensive business model in order to cement its market position in AI compute. To enable this shift, Oracle raised $18bn in debt in 2025 (o ff a base of $80bn) and plans to raise $38bn in the medium term. Oracle has commented that in aggregate, it can fund its OCI expansion plans with less than $100bn in new capital raises. The pace and scale of capital commitments coupled with outsized customer concentration with OpenAI is creating renewed focus on Oracle's creditworthiness. For example, Oracle's CDS has historically traded in line with CDX IG, but since 2Q earnings the spread has widened to 100bps+. While Oracle's 5YR CDS is approaching 150bps, and is now 100bps above the IG benchmark, we'd note that pricing 'only' 140bps above the risk free rate does not imply an outsized amount of credit risk. Moreover, when taking a closer look at the trading dynamics of Oracle's debt tranches, its highest YTW is

~7% - that is, debt investors are asking for a 200bp premium (vs. the
