A key debate on Oracle's investment strategy is whether these data centers will be fungible between types of workloads (training vs. inference) and types of customers (OpenAI vs. others). - Training involves optimizing a model's parameters to minimize error on a given n dataset, demanding substantial computational power for extensive matrix 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 multiplications, high compute throughput, and parallelism, and often requiring weeks or months of continuous operation. Consequently, training requires vast memory to store billions or trillions of parameters and intermediate results, typically scaling across distributed clusters and high-performance computing (HPC) environments, relying heavily on specialized hardware accelerators. Latency is generally not critical during training, as the process can span extended periods.

- AI inference is the execution phase where a trained model is deployed to make n predictions or decisions, with the primary objective of delivering fast predictions for real-world applications. While less computationally intensive per instance compared to training, inference often requires moderate computational power focused on real-time processing, and total compute usage can become extremely large at scale - thus while the cost per inference instance is lower, continuous operations can lead to substantial overall expenses leading to a focus on lowering costs per query. Inference can be deployed on a wider range of hardware, including CPUs, GPUs, ASICs, and specialized edge devices, and can scale from edge devices to cloud systems. The critical distinction between inference and training is latency: low latency is paramount for inference, especially in real-time applications like autonomous vehicles, chatbots, and recommendation engines, often requiring sub-millisecond responses.

| Tr a inin g                                                                                                                                                                                            |                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Inf e r e n ce                |
|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------|
| • High-end, dense GPU clusters • Faster turnover as new GPUs improve leading each performance • High sustained utilization to support burst-style training runs                                        | • Mix of GPUs, CPUs, and accelerators • Optimized for cost-per-query rather than FLOPs • Longer depreciation cycles • Utilization varies with traffic, prioritizing responsiveness & throughput | Co mpu te                     |
| • East-West (GPU to GPU) traffic within data center fabric                                                                                                                                             | • North-South (client to server) traffic requires efficient load balancing and caching • Sophisticated workload routing algorithms to minimize latency                                          | N et w o rkin g               |
| • Extremely high power density, heavy use of liquid cooling, requiring multi- hundredMW campuses • Grid reliability is critical • High up-front GPU + infrastructure cost amortized over training runs | • Lower power density, can run smaller regional data centers distributed near users for edge cases • Lower capex per site                                                                       | P o w e r/ Coo lin g /L a n d |

Oracle's current large-scale AI contracts are structured as take-or-pay contracts: customers are committed to multi-year commitments guaranteeing a fi xed minimum spend on OCI resources regardless of usage . Thus, regardless of whether a customer is at 2% or 100% utilization in a data center, revenue is consistent through the length of the contract once capacity is available to the customer. So over the length of these contracts, the question of fungibility is generally irrelevant. However, we note the delta between contract terms and lease terms: the Oracle/OpenAI $300bn contract is over fi ve years, while the contract leases are generally longer (for example, the Abilene, Texas data center is leased from Crusoe in a 15-year lease). The question then arises whether Oracle can transition its data centers currently optimized for training workloads to inference use cases in 2030 when its large-scale training contracts expire and it has 10 years remaining on its data center lease.

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 In our view, the biggest barriers to converting a data center from training to inference are: 1) latency - training clusters are built as centralized supercomputers, not for the low-latency, north-south access from users. A training campus in a remote region may have excellent internal networking, but the inherent network geography and user-proximity requirements make large training campuses structurally unsuited for latency-critical serving; and 2) cost optimization - training campuses are designed for maximum performance per watt, not minimum cost per query. Inference economics are focused on cost per token and can run on lower-cost, lower-power accelerators that deliver better throughput-per-dollar.

Oracle's comments indicate that they have been able to convert a data center from training workloads to inference workloads as quickly as one weekend (this is clearly a best case scenario). Thus, it is possible to transition these workloads - however, we recognize that there are still several unknowns on the long-term (2030+) ability of training-optimized campuses to fully support inference use cases given latency-sensitivity and a mismatch of cost optimization between performance per watt vs. cost per query.

We assume coverage with a Buy rating and a 12-month Price Target of $240. Our valuation methodology is based on non-GAAP P/E. We apply a 20x P/E multiple to Oracle's 2030 adjusted net income, discounted back to SNTM (Q5-Q8) to be consistent with our broader coverage framework. This implies a SNTM P/E multiple of 33x. We believe it is fair to give credit to Oracle out to 2030 given the business composition shift and period of hyper-growth it is entering as it delivers on signi fi cant backlog already contracted, though note that we are signi fi cantly below Street estimates (~25% below 2030 EPS) given we discount Oracle's targets by 30% to account for customer concentration risk and execution risk of data center buildouts. Nonetheless, our scenario analysis in Section 3 above indicates an attractive risk/reward skew.

Our comp group is made up of technology companies with gross margins in the 50-80% range (to account for our expectation of gross margin degradation ~20% between FY25 and FY30) and EPS growth ~5-20% (to account for GSe EPS CAGR ~20% from FY25-FY30). We apply a 20x multiple, which is a 20% discount to peers (median P/E multiple of 25x) to account for a) Oracle's EPS growth likely approaching the mid-20s vs. peers at 15%; more than o ff set by b) execution risk tied to data center build out timing, GPU cycles and pricing, energy costs, and mega-tenant concentration. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 We detail several of the key risks to the OpenAI contract in particular in our Bear n Case analysis above Risks to IaaS build out: The timing and execution of data center build-outs are a n signi fi cant risk, with potential delays due to supply chain disruptions, regulatory hurdles, or real estate challenges hindering expansion and capacity to meet growing demand. OCI's reliance on high-performance compute exposes it to GPU cycles and pricing volatility; shortages or signi fi cant cost increases for GPU could impact OCI's service delivery, cost structure, and competitive pricing. Escalating energy costs pose a threat given the energy intensity of these data centers. Signi fi cant customer concentration risk given OCI's revenue is currently highly levered to OpenAI, making it vulnerable to spending fl uctuations or potential churn.

Intense capex investment cycle: This cycle is expected to pressure FCF generation n to fi nance these large-scale investments, Oracle is resorting to external funding, often through issuing new debt, but this increased debt burden leads to higher interest expenses, further reducing net income and cash fl ow available for other purposes, and can potentially impact the company's credit rating and fi nancial fl exibility. Accelerating share losses in the database/SaaS market as hyperscalers and n pure-plays displace Oracle on-prem databases and SaaS solutions with cloud-native o ff erings 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We assume coverage of Salesforce (CRM) with a Buy and 27% upside to our 12 month price target of $330. Salesforce's vision with Agentforce outlines a future for agentic adoption in the front o ffi ce wherein AI functionality is a natural extension of existing technology strengths in Sales and Service. We expect Agentforce success to be the main driver of stock outperformance over the medium term, and therefore focus our analysis on this segment. Our industry conversations suggest that Salesforce's customer feedback loops are e ff ective and there is steady progress on some of the key limiting factors to Agentforce adoption. Rather than a binary view where Agentforce either works or doesn't, our base case is more nuanced: we expect to see a 4% tailwind to Platform and Other revenue over the next 12-18 months, which our bottom up build and Salesforce disclosures suggest will be enough to drive a revenue in fl ection as early as 2026. Over the FY26-FY30 time frame, we expect

that Agentforce will represent a 2% tailwind for the business in aggregate. Our view also takes into account ongoing share loss in Commerce and Marketing Cloud and evolving approaches to data architecture that impact Data 360 (formerly known as Data Cloud). Taken together, we see a positive risk/reward, and expect more consistent signs of momentum across the customer base through FY27 to catalyze stock outperformance.

Path to Agentforce adoption: As a starting point for quantifying growth, we 1. estimate that 20% of Salesforce customers in Sales/Service/Platform areas are showing interest in Agentforce, with 50% of those customers then moving on to a POC (10% of total customers), and then 25% of POC customers converting (2-3% of total customers). We expect Agentforce adoption to be gradual, and our base case assumes that this ramps from 2-3% of each segment (ex. Sales, Service, etc.) converting in FY26 to 13% of each segment converting in FY30. We assume that Agentforce adoption will be more straightforward for Sales/Service/Platform use cases vs. Marketing and Commerce - and that Marketing and Commerce Agentforce adoption lags the leading modules by 2 years. This results in ~40% penetration of Agentforce in Sales/Service/Platform respectively by 2030 and 17% penetration in Marketing and Commerce - re fl ecting our view that a signi fi cant portion of Salesforce customers will fi nd

value in adopting Agentforce, but that this is not a zero sum game, with a number of customers that will decide to adopt AI through di ff erent avenues. Monetization of Agentforce: In our base case we benchmark to a 25% contract 2. uplift from Agentforce in each segment (given each segment represents some portion of the overall ELA, which our industry conversations suggest typically sees a 20% uplift). We see this as a potential driver of upside as enterprises become more comfortable with expanding Agentforce use cases as the ROI continues to improve over time. This is particularly true in Service where our proprietary ROI builds suggest that Agents are capable of taking share of labor budgets (particularly for text-based use cases), expanding the TAM more quanti fi ably. Near term catalyst path: We expect improving sentiment around Agentforce in the 3. partner and customer ecosystem. Through our conversations, we heard optimism in 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

the ability for Agentforce to be adopted over time, as customers grapple with the associated costs, security concerns, and noise from other vendors, such that Salesforce provides a path of least resistance vs. other vendors. While enterprises will likely implement a variety of routes to incorporate agentic technology, most organizations are under pressure from C-suites to deliver, and we expect that Salesforce can capture share of this demand.

- FY2030 Model: Our base case for Agentforce is that it can ramp to $4bn in revenue 4. by FY30, implying that the rest of Salesforce's business has to grow at an 8% CAGR between FY26-FY30 in order for the company to reach the $60bn target in FY2030 (excluding Informatica). We believe this will be supported by a continued mix shift in growth contribution as Platform and Other revenue increases as a portion of overall revenue and Marketing and Commerce declines. As part of this, we believe that Platform and Other revenue will have to sustain a low-to-mid teens growth rate ex. Agentforce, which can be achieved through the continued ramp of Data 360 given that it is highly complementary to Agentforce.

Background: Salesforce introduced Agentforce in August 2024 as the next evolution of its front o ffi ce platform. Agentforce re-imagines core knowledge worker work fl ows with agentic augmentation to drive productivity improvements. Through our conversations with front o ffi ce disruptors such as Braze, Klaviyo, Sierra and Decagon, we have historically viewed Salesforce as having a high amount of technical debt (commensurate with key architectural decisions being made in the 2001-2005 time frame), with this being a limiting factor to agent performance (eg. accuracy and latency). However, today we do not believe that Salesforce's architecture is a meaningful limiting factor to Agentforce in Service and Sales for several reasons:

Salesforce underwent a signi fi cant technology replatforming prior to 2024, key n aspects of this are detailed here (Blog: The Salesforce Platform - Transformed for Tomorrow): Hyperforce (introduced in 2020) : This is the current generation of Salesforce's o infrastructure, and part of the transition from proprietary data centers to a globally distributed architecture on public clouds. Hyperforce is designed to meet customer needs for scale, global data residency, enhanced availability, security, and regulatory compliance across more than 20 regions worldwide.

Shift from monolithic to independent services: The move to independent o services aligns with microservices architecture principles, where application components are decoupled into small, independently deployable services. Each service is responsible for a speci fi c business function and can operate autonomously. This modularity allows for better code organization, easier maintenance, and the ability to update or replace individual services without a ff ecting the entire system. Importantly, the core of Salesforce's platform continues to run as a single system of record for application metadata. This includes a metadata framework which provides a stable abstraction layer for applications, allowing them to be built on evolving underlying technologies (Exhibit 75). 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

| M etadata Fr a m e w o rk   | M etadata Fr a m e w o rk   | M etadata Fr a m e w o rk                  | M etadata Fr a m e w o rk                                                                     |
|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|--------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| App Sp ace                  | Layer 4                     | End user customization                     | Saved in user metadata                                                                        |
| App Sp ace                  | Layer 3                     | Admin Authored Features                    | Deployed through: Direct Metadata Save Controlled by: Org Admins/Developers                   |
| App Sp ace                  | Layer 2                     | Partner Authored Features                  | Deployed through: Packaged Metadata Controlled by: ISV/Partner Developers (or Org Controlled) |
| Pl at f o rm Sp ace         | Layer 1                     | Salesforce Authored Features (In-platform) | Deployed through: Standard Metadata Controlled by: Salesforce Developers                      |

AI and Agentforce: Signi fi cant advancements in AI, including machine learning, n generative AI, and agentic experiences, are integrated into the platform. Agentforce, in particular, is highlighted as an AI-native platform designed to deliver intelligent, personalized, and e ff ective business solutions by combining predictive and generative AI. Agentforce 3.0 is built on an asynchronous, event-driven architecture with multimodal voice capabilities, which we believe has been a tough technical challenge to solve. Data 360 works as a stop gap measure to harmonize data across the clouds. While n most enterprise customers already have a sophisticated data strategy built on best in breed data warehouses like Snow fl ake and Databricks, we view Data 360 as 'the easy button' to harmonize customer data speci fi cally for Agentforce use cases. All Agentforce deployments e ff ectively must come with a base level SKU of Data 360 that includes platform enhancements such as Agentforce data libraries, session tracing data models for debug logs, structured and unstructured data retrievers.

One of the biggest di ff erentiators of Salesforce today is the platform expertise that n supports them. There is an entire ecosystem (ex. Flows and Apex) that exists that can help solve customer data estate challenges and is already entrenched in the Salesforce ecosystem. Additionally, Salesforce is the de-facto solution for sales reps and as such has become a critical tool required for organizations looking to attract

Data: The platform has evolved to incorporate Data 360 and Lakehouse o technologies alongside traditional relational data stores, simplifying the management of large data volumes and enabling real-time data processing. The traditional data store (SalesforceDB) continues to be important for managing SoR data e ff ectively, which is then ingested into Data 360. Data 360 is a hyperscale data lakehouse platform that uni fi es customer data from diverse sources, both structured and unstructured, to provide a comprehensive and real-time view. A key technical aspect is its 'zero-copy' integration, which allows it to access and use external data from various data warehouses and lakes (like Snow fl ake or Databricks) without moving or duplicating it, leveraging open formats like Apache Iceberg and Parquet.

Application Suite: Salesforce has rebuilt Marketing Cloud, Revenue Cloud, o and Commerce Cloud on the Salesforce platform, such that they bene fi t from all the foundational elements from the replatforming. Our industry conversations suggests that this is a continual e ff ort as Salesforce works to include more functionality in these rebuilt products over time. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 or retain top sales talent. This adds to the stickiness of the product, and we believe makes it more likely for organizations to incorporate agentic technology via Salesforce for these personas in order to streamline processes and reduce the number of tools that are needed (vendor consolidation has been a powerful theme over the past 3 years as enterprises look to reduce the number of vendors in their tech stacks).

- We believe AI protocols and API-based technologies will make it easier to connect n data across di ff erent architectures. This includes MCP (Model Context Protocal) which allows Generative AI models to dynamically retrieve necessary data directly from source systems on demand, eliminating the need for data copying or syncing. This also increases the importance of the MuleSoft in 2018. Mulesoft helps connect Salesforce with a wide array of disparate systems using reusable APIs, including on-premises legacy applications, other cloud platforms (like SAP or Oracle), and custom-built solutions. The question then becomes: what are the limiting factors to Agentforce deployment from a technical and go to market standpoint, and how does it contribute to the growth algorithm?

Customers now have more control over where they want outputs to be on the o spectrum of deterministic to probabilistic (ex. Agentforce studio). Voice now works as a channel (Salesforce discussed voice at Agentforce 2024 o but our industry conversations suggest it was only e ff ectively introduced in 2025) Resolution rates are on par or approaching AI native pure plays (vs. Sierra, o Decagon), currently in the 50-80% range depending on the customer but internally Salesforce is able to drive an 86% resolution rate. This is likely weighted toward text-based channels. The SI ecosystem is maturing - for example, we spoke to one large NA SI that o deployed a product wizard and customer service agent for a $20bn athletic retailer that has streamlined a 6-7 month custom deployment into a playbook that is repeatable.

Latency is still an issue. In our conversations, more than one industry o participant speci fi cally highlighted faster responsiveness from a DIY solution built on Anthropic. Some work fl ows are still not integrated well e.g. customers have to copy/paste o AI generated emails into core Salesforce work fl ows. Quality is still an issue. For example, our observations engaging with the o Williams Sonoma customer service agent suggest that multiple loops are required to get to a reasonable answer for a questions on types of pans to use for speci fi c recipes, or more speci fi c prompts for hostess gifts. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

The level of concern around privacy and security from regulated industries o ( fi nancials, healthcare) is still very high. Salesforce has introduced hashing of queried private data to help address this; i.e. sensitive customer information in the context of the query will be hashed before the query is sent out to the LLM. However, there is still an active debate over what privacy controls will ultimately be su ffi cient for adoption. A number of Salesforce customers are on older versions of the platform that o they have built signi fi cant customizations around. These customizations can make it impossible to adopt Agentforce technology. A customer interested in Salesforce Voice might be unable to adopt it before embarking on a much larger platform upgrade with Salesforce due to the customizations built on their older version of the stack. This is particularly true in Marketing and Commerce where a lot of the heavy lifting around improving these products has been done, but many customers are not on these improved versions today.

M&A: Many of these limiting factors can be addressed through a combination of n organic and inorganic development. For example, Salesforce announced 9 acquisitions in 2025, many aimed at improving Agentforce capabilities. This represents a step up from 4 deals in 2024 and 1 deals in 2023. Given the level of noise in the startup ecosystem, we expect that there will continue to be opportunities for Salesforce to acquire innovative technology from the private markets in order to keep pace with the level of innovation we are seeing in that ecosystem. Informatica: Salesforce believes that Informatica can help Agentforce o through its rich data catalog, data integration, governance, quality and privacy, metadata management, and MDM capabilities. We see this acquisition as a way for Salesforce to address many of the concerns that enterprises have today with both data hygiene and security concerns. We look to better understand the timeline in which this technology can be integrated in order to start addressing these concerns and help enterprises ramp Agentforce adoption (Data 360).

Regrello: Agentic process automation, turning data into agentic work fl ows o (Slack). Apromore: Intelligence platform for business processes o (Agentforce/Analytics). Bluebirds: AI powered platform for top-of-funnel prospecting (Sales). o Convergence.AI: Helps with AI agent development, particularly with complex o work fl ows (Agentforce). Doti: Agentic enterprise search (Slack). o Spindle AI: Agentic analytics platform that combines agents and machine o learning (Agentforce). One of the more striking observations to us from Dreamforce 2025 is the degree to n which large enterprises rely on Salesforce to guide them through front o ffi ce digital transformation. We believe the strategic nature of these relationships are a function of 20+ years of driving leadership in Sales cloud, which is arguably the most mission critical business enablement tool in an organization, and ranks higher in the budget stack than many other line items (e.g. we estimate front o ffi ce software ranks in the top quartile of budget line items in a typical large enterprise and CRM is the largest area of enterprise software spend globally). At a higher level: We believe Salesforce sells sales software well because they are good at every level of selling: the executive team has deep relationships with C-level leaders at customers; and conferences like Agentforce on Tour and Dreamforce facilitate networking and best practices at a greater scale than we've observed at prior conferences.

While Agentforce is too important of an investment to bene fi t from traditional n principles of virality (eg. typically new Salesforce products are easier to sell into its install base, however we don't expect this to be true for Agentforce due to the mission critical nature of the product), we do think the reference selling model will hold over time. As Chairman and CEO Mr. Benio ff discussed in October: fl agship customers such as Disney, Williams Sonoma and Pepsi will set the bar for agentic transformation in a way that creates competitive intensify: adopt, or be left behind. The go to market evolution includes innovations such as AELAs (Agentic Enterprise n License Agreements) to help customers budget

What does this mean for numbers - deconstructing Salesforce's $60bn FY30 target Salesforce introduced FY30 targets at Dreamforce in October 2025: $60 bn in revenue, with a 10% CAGR 2025-2030, and a Rule of 50 pro fi le (implies low 40s margin at a high single digit growth rate in 2030). For FY26 (Jan), Salesforce is on track for 9% revenue growth and 34% margin. Our analysis aims to break down the key building blocks of the growth algorithm to determine a) how realistic the 2030 targets are and a reasonable upside case; b) the potential catalyst path (both upside and downside) that could drive outsized stock moves. Our forecast takes into account several key principles:

Agentforce adoption will be more meaningful in Service and Sales, in turn pulling n through Data 360. This comprises 50% of Salesforce's mix. This is a combination of a) Salesforce having the strongest technology o ff erings in these two segments; b) these two segments showing the most e ff ective use cases (measurable ROI, veri fi able outcomes). These use cases speci fi cally include agents for Customer Service queries, and coaching for sales people (such as prompts for best responses). Agentforce adoption will be limited in Commerce and Marketing, pending a n heightened pace of product innovation. In Commerce, we believe mid market and even large enterprises are increasingly standardizing on Shopify (we expect Shopify Plus MRR will be up close to +30% yoy in 2025, accelerating versus 2024) and it will 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

take time for Salesforce to refresh its roadmap and execute on tangible improvements to stem churn. In Marketing, we believe that Salesforce is behind on several product cycles (such as omnichannel analytics), the ecosystem is shifting away from them, and that competition has intensi fi ed. Without a clear technology leadership position, we believe it will be challenging for Salesforce to introduce and monetize compelling agentic tools. (Put simply, the base product has to be very good today for customers to commit to a longer AI journey).

Platform revenue can sustain low-to-mid teens growth, supported by Agentforce n adoption at the platform layer, Data 360's importance in realizing value from agents, and Slack becoming more di ff erentiated given its importance in work fl ows that will be augmented by AI. AI will expand the software TAM by over 20% in 2030 in Service and Sales. This is n based on our bottom up analysis of ROI in the call center using both value-based and cost-based pricing models, with key variables being de fl ection rates and cost per conversation. Our value-based analysis assumes that software provides capture 10-20% of the productivity improvements they deliver to customers (see our TAM & Framework section for more detail).

Based on our customer conversations, we estimate there is a similar 20% uplift on n deal sizes when customers adopt Agentforce. While early customers may have gotten preferential pricing, we also see the potential for upside to initial agreements (as customers are only likely to commit to deal sizes that re fl ect their current AI adoption expectations, which could ultimately surprise to the upside as new features are launched). As such, we can model cohorts over time to cross-test our 2030 forecast. We expect Agentforce revenue to have healthy expansion given the consumption based revenue model & natural roll out of AI solutions across an organization. Integration and Analytics revenue will bene fi t from the value of MuleSoft's data n connection capabilities, partially o ff set by Tableau where we see more likelihood of disintermediation. Competition: Changes in the competitive environment could hurt Salesforce. The n competitive environment has been particularly dynamic given the explosion of AI driven startups and concerns that players at the infrastructure or platform level could become competitive in the application layer. Agentforce Adoption: Lower or slower adoption of Agentforce vs. expectations. n The rollout of AI across enterprises has been slow and behind investor expectations due to the complexity of deployments, internal change management, and noise in the ecosystem distracting customers. If less customers vs. our expectations decide to adopt Agentforce or if it takes longer for Salesforce to acquire and monetize customers, there could be downside to our forecasts. M&A: Salesforce is highly acquisitive and as such we see the potential for M&A to act n as a negative risk. For example, deals that bring higher integration costs, cause near term business disruption, negatively impact the fi nancial pro fi le of the company, or don't result in a positive return on investment could all be drivers of downside.

Margins : Salesforce has recently expanded margins meaningfully. If the company n decided to invest more vs. our expectations in a way that resulted in pro fi tability pressure, the stock could see downside. Additionally, if the company looks to drive too much margin expansion such that they do not invest enough for growth, there

We assume coverage of ServiceNow (NOW) with a Buy rating and 40% upside to our 12-month price target of $205. We see a high liklihood of ServiceNow sustaining a ~20% organic CAGR through 2029 as it leans into still-robust expansion opportunities in new domains such as Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), and Human Capital Management (HCM). We believe share gain momentum is a function of ServiceNow's unique positioning as a work fl ow engine (rather than a system of record), including via its uni fi ed multi-instance architecture and its deep connectivity that enables actions in adjacent systems. On AI, we see two ways NOW is uniquely positioned: fi rst, as an orchestration engine that manages AI deployments broadly through tools like AI control tower; and second, as delivering direct productivity improvements and taking share from the labor budgets that sit next to functions such as the IT help desk.

Lastly, ServiceNow's expanding real estate in the tech stack coupled with its willingness to engage in M&A position the company well for adjacencies in Security.

- 1. Bridging to 20% organic growth in each of the next 3 years ServiceNow's transition from IT-centric work fl ows to an orchestration engine that spans multiple applications (ERP, CRM, HCM, etc.) is well underway. ServiceNow's origins are as an IT service management (ITSM) platform, digitizing IT help desk and operation work fl ows alongside the last 20 years of enterprise modernization. The company has increasingly applied its core work fl ow engine as a horizontal plaform (the Now Platform) to drive productivity growth across existing ERP, CRM, and HCM systems. Rather than a system of record, ServiceNow is a system of action that connects siloed applications, and its success today is a function of its core competencies with integrations and a single code base. As a result, while enterprise SaaS peers' have decelerated by ~25 pts post COVID (1Q22 to 4Q25E), ServiceNow's growth has slowed by 7 points. ServiceNow's ability

to maintain a steady level of growth at its scale of $13bn ARR is best in class among software companies, and a key debate for the stock is its ability to maintain ~20% growth rates over the near to medium term.

- Customer and Industry Work fl ows: ServiceNow launched its Customer Service n Management (CSM) solution in 2016, designed to unify front/middle/back-o ffi ce operations so that customer issues could be solved across department domains and across service agents, fi eld teams, and IT systems. Building on this, ServiceNow launched industry speci fi c verticals (i.e. fi nancial services, healthcare, manufacturing, telecom, etc.), and platform solutions such as sales and order management (launched in 2024) to manage the sales lifecycle. The acquisition of Logik.ai in April 2025 further bolstered its AI-powered CRM and Sales Order Management capabilities, particularly for complex Con fi gure, Price, Quote (CPQ) solutions (a particular industry pain point per our industry conversations). Across these developments, ServiceNow has shifted its positioning in the CRM market from being complementary to being directly competitive. Our industry conversations 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

suggest ServiceNow remains behind leaders on traditional CRM functions in core front-o ffi ce functions tied to sales, marketing, and customer acquisitions, such as lead generation and campaign management, sales pipeline management, and account management. Instead, its strength is in post-sale customer operations. However, ServiceNow is actively expanding its capabilities, such as via the acquisition of Logik.ai for CPQ. We expect ServiceNow to continue its push into core sales work fl ows: while our industry checks have brought up examples of Salesforce rip and replace, we believe the most likely scenario is that ServiceNow consistently abstracts value from these platforms by sitting alongside them.

Employee Work fl ows: ServiceNow has also moved into employee-facing n applications and HCM. Its HCM solutions typically function as a 'system of experience' that sit on top of existing HCM software vendors rather than replacing them as a system of record. ServiceNow leverages its work fl ow automation to automate HR processes, such as employee onboarding, by treating them similarly to IT service tickets. It integrates with existing HCM systems to expand HR and IT capabilities, automate repetitive tasks, and ensure smoother data fl ows.

Creator & Other Work fl ows: This is a comprehensive suite of tools and capabilities n that enables users of all technical skill levels to build, deploy, and manage custom applications and automate work fl ows on the Now Platform. It is largely synonymous with ServiceNow's App Engine, which serves as the underlying platform for these development activities. These work fl ows are low-code/no-code development, enabling users from professional developers to business users to automate and digitize manual processes, optimize service delivery, drive digital transformation, and create custom solutions tailored to unique business needs across various departments. Risk & Security Work fl ows: See more details below n Exhibit 82: New ACV mix by work fl ow shows ServiceNow continues to expand out of core IT work fl ows Source: Company data We introduce a market share analysis of ServiceNow's current breakdown by work fl ow, using disclosure of ACV as a proxy for subscription revenue, to inform our view of sustained 20% growth.

- ServiceNow discloses yearly ACV across customer and industry, employee, and n 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 creator work fl ows. We estimate historical security work fl ow ACV based on Gartner revenue estimates and company disclosure. We back into implied tech work fl ows assuming it is the remainder of subscription revenue. We then estimate market share by work fl ow. As ServiceNow typically operates as the n system of action rather than the system of record (which the market data skews toward), we apply a % multiplier to the Gartner estimate based on ServiceNow's product o ff erings and maturity in an attempt to more accurately capture ServiceNow's serviceable addressable market. This analysis is illustrative, but we believe it is a good starting point to determine ServiceNow's current penetration and reasonable medium-term growth algorithm across these work fl ows.

From this market share analysis, we arrive at estimated market share gains by n considering the trend and competitive dynamics through 2028 in each of the work fl ows, arriving at ~15% market share in FY28 (vs. ~12% in FY24). Based on this base case, we see ServiceNow poised to grow 21%/20%/18% over FY26/27/28 these estimates are 1%/2%/2% above the Street and imply a 20% CAGR from FY24 to FY28. Importantly, these estimates are based on the current trendlines and do not assume any upside potential from increased enterprise AI adoption.

Potential upside tied to ServiceNow's AI strategy We believe there may be upside to our base case model driven by increased adoption of ServiceNow's AI solutions. In our view, ServiceNow is one of the best positioned incumbent SaaS provider to establish itself as an orchestration layer across di ff erent knowledge work fl ows because it is already embedded across multiple enterprise work fl ows (ITSM broadly, HR, Finance, and increasingly CRM).

ServiceNow's Work fl ow Data Fabric and RaptorDB technology are foundational building blocks designed to support agentic deployment: Work fl ow Data Fabric (WDF) is the integration and semantic layer - it connects n business and technology data, processes it in context via a uni fi ed model, and takes action by triggering work fl ows without moving the data (with Zero Copy connectors across databases like Snow fl ake, Databricks, BigQuery, etc.). WDF was part of ServiceNow's broader shift towards being an enterprise orchestration layer, making work fl ows data-aware to enable Now Platform automations to act across HR, IT, fi nance, customer service, etc. use cases. Work fl ow Data Fabric enables continuous operational improvement, faster enterprise-wide integration (up to 6x faster), and a reduction in TCO by up to 70% (vs. third-party iPaaS solutions).

RaptorDB is ServiceNow's Hybrid Transactional and Analytical Processing n (HTAP) database speci fi cally engineered for ServiceNow workloads. Based on PostgreSQL open-source standards and enhanced through ServiceNow's acquisition of Swarm64 in 2021 (a database software accelerator), RaptorDB serves as the foundational data layer to deliver faster work fl ow performance - one customer saw >4x improvement in SQL response time, 73% faster report loading, and an 80% reduction in UI response time. RaptorDB Standard improves scale and performance for workloads and queries; RaptorDB Pro is the premium version with advanced features such as: 1) HTAP architecture; 2) integrated column-store index, accelerating reporting and query time; 3) built-in parallel processing allowing the system to handle heavy tra ffi c and large datasets; and 4) performance improvements in transaction times.

Together, WDF and RaptorDB are enablers for agentic deployment within the ServiceNow ecosystem . Work fl ow Data Fabric ensures that AI agents have real-time, secure, and contextual access to data from any source. This data context allows agents to act intelligently and autonomously, making informed decisions and executing complex tasks. RaptorDB Pro's speed and scalability reduce performance bottlenecks because agentic work fl ows often involve both real time transactional actions and analytical queries, RaptorDB supports both with its HTAP system. This results in quicker insights and the ability to take immediate action, even with massive datasets and high transactional volumes.

With WDF and RaptorDB as the core building blocks, ServiceNow's agentic portfolio is built on four product pillars that transform intent into outcomes: prebuilt and domain-speci fi c agents (Now Assist), low/no -code builder tools (AI Agent Studio and Build Agent), multi -agent coordination layers (AI Agent Orchestrator and AI Agent Fabric), and a uni fi ed entry point (AI Experience): - NowAssist: ServiceNow o ff ers thousands of prebuilt AI agents embedded into n 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

ServiceNow work fl ows, including summarization of cases, virtual agent responses, and code/ fl ow generation. In CRM, CRM AI agents autonomously orchestrate and complete tasks across the customer lifecycle of selling, ful fi lling, and servicing. Where traditional automation requires pre-de fi ned rules, these agents dynamically determine the best course of action by resolving inquiries, routing complex cases with full context, and managing work fl ows across departments. Internally at ServiceNow, these agents are automating 37% of internal customer support case work fl ows. Momentum is picking up with NowAssist: in May 2025, management discussed 50% growth in usage month over month; by November 2025, consumption had increased 55x+ since the end of May.

AI Agent Studio & Build Agent: AI Agent Studio streamlines building and composing n agents with guided, natural-language setup and adds dashboards tying usage, quality, and value to business KPIs for lifecycle management. Build Agent brings 'vibe coding' to the enterprise - it enables creators to describe an app in natural language and receive a production-ready application equipped with audit trails, security, and compliance. AI Agent Orchestrator/AI Agent Fabric: AI Agent Orchestrator enables inter-agent n communication and centralized coordination so agents can share context and hand o ff across systems - for example, a customer onboarding process that spans multiple tools and teams. AI Agent Fabric is the communication backbone for heterogeneous ecosystems, supporting protocols such as MCP and A2A to connect ServiceNow and third-party agents and tools.

AI Experience: AI Experience is a conversational interface to Enterprise AI. It n provides a context -aware front door with instant access to text, voice, image, web, and build agents across any work fl ow, including the autonomous CRM o ff ering. All of these agentic portfolios are uni fi ed under AI Control Tower, which is the centralized command center to govern, manage, secure, and realize value from any ServiceNow or third-party AI agent, model, and work fl ow. The Control Tower provides a single view of every AI asset with consistent policies applied across the estate - it helps align AI programs to enterprise strategy by tracking adoption, value creation, and governance postures across the portfolio.

Monetization Considerations: ServiceNow's core is a seat-based subscription model where customers pay for user licenses, with revenue recognized ratably over the contract term. There is a tiered product structure with three pricing levels: 1) Standard edition, the entry-level o ff ering with core functionality (~45% of customer accounts for ITSM/CSM); 2) Pro edition, with enhanced capabilities (~49%). The Pro SKUs have ~25% price uplift over standard; and 3) the Pro Plus edition, with AI capabilities and advanced features (~6%). The Pro Plus SKUs have ~30% price uplift over pro.

ServiceNow has also introduced a hybrid pricing model for AI Capabilities (Now Assist), combining the traditional subscription model with a consumption element. Customers purchase a base subscription for Now Assist Usage, which includes a fi nite amount of tokens or capacity for AI usage burned down based on actual usage. Once the initial capacity is exhausted, customers can purchase additional 'assist packs' without a full subscription renewal, with consumption tracked through 'assists.' Each interaction with AI agents counts towards this consumption. Management expects the consumption of 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

assists with AI will be a multiple factor higher than a standard Now Assist query as customers adopt more complex AI work fl ows. Material monetization on the consumption side isn't expected to impact the model until 2027 as customers consume their tokens and purchase additional capacity. In the near-term, AI is increasingly pulling customers up the pricing stack - Pro penetration was up 10% (from 45% to 55%) as of the May 2025 investor day, and 15% of the customers on Standard that upgraded in 2024 went straight to Pro Plus to leverage agentic capabilities (with ~60% average realized price uplift for these double upgrades).

ServiceNow's AI platform is the fastest growing product family in its history, with 1,000 customers using the platform and $250mn+ in ACV as of May 2025 - management expects NowAssist ACV contribution to reach $1bn by 2026. As of 3Q, ServiceNow was on track to exceed $500mn in ACV. We believe that ServiceNow's AI strategy positions it well to capture an increasing share of AI budgets, with medium-term opportunity as revenue contributions scale more meaningfully in 2027 as usage ramps and Assist packs gain traction.

Incremental to the internal agentic development is the Moveworks acquisition (closed 12/16), which combines ServiceNow's work fl ow automation and existing AI solutions with Moveworks' front-end conversational AI and enterprise search capabilities. Moveworks brings a natural language interface that enables employees to resolve IT, HR, and business issues through chat-based interactions while ServiceNow's platform executes and orchestrates the requests. Their platform is built on top of a blend of foundation models, SLM task-speci fi c models, and their custom MoveLM model (providing industry, domain and company-speci fi c vocabulary and work fl ows) to improve the accuracy of responses. With $100mn in ARR in 2024 and 5mn users, we view this acquisition as ServiceNow seeing a gap in its functionality and accelerating its time to market by moving to acquire (vs. build in house). meaningful new product cycle for ServiceNow over the next 5 years . Based on ServiceNow's public commentary and our discussions in industry, we think select Security functionality a) sits adjacent to ServiceNow's existing positioning in the technology stack; b) leverages its core strengths; c) is a large enough TAMs to move the needle at ServiceNow's current scale. ServiceNow disclosed over $1bn in ACV tied to Risk and Security work fl ows (which is included within tech work fl ows). We see a scenario where ServiceNow's AI functionality could increasingly complement or abstract governance functionality from IGA tools, particularly given the white space associated with agentic (i.e. there is no standardized playbook on how to secure agents). As a case study, consider the move to cloud, where a portion of the cloud security opportunity was captured by IaaS vendors. Similarly, we believe a portion of the identity governance opportunity may be captured by AI platform vendors like ServiceNow in

tools such as the AI control tower. We spoke to one ServiceNow customer who tried to use AI builder to augment its SailPoint budget: while this project worked as a prototype but ultimately did not make it into production, it is illustrative of the potential for ServiceNow to expand into more explicit governance use cases. Lastly, we believe ServiceNow does not have strong technology today that runs at the kernel level (our understanding is its tools primarily run in the user space). Kernel level access could improve the depth of data and control that ServiceNow has in its environments, and could be acquired via select endpoint or cloud workload protection (CWP) assets. ServiceNow recently announced its planned acquisition of Veza , which supports broad IGA capabilities including access reviews, access requests, and an access hub, AI A ge n t O r c h est r ato r: Enables inter-agent communication and centralized coordination so agents can share context and hand off across systems

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 along with permission updates and end-to-end visibility. Veza's Access Graph gives organizations a single dashboard to quickly spot and remedy overly broad permissions across both human and machine identities, including AI agents. Founded in 2020, Veza serves nearly 150 global enterprise customers in banking, hospitality, and fast-moving consumer goods, with 230 employees globally. Terms of the transaction were undisclosed, though reports indicated a transaction value of $1bn+.

ServiceNow plans to integrate Veza's Access Graph with ServiceNow's AI Control Tower and agentic work fl ows to provide a single pane of glass and control of every identity in an organization. Veza would also add identity context to existing ServiceNow Security and Risk products, including Vulnerability Response, Incident Response, and Integrated Risk Management, giving customers a clearer view of who and what is associated with an exposure, incident, or risk event. Identity security is increasingly becoming a core pillar of Security Operations, and we believe Veza would strengthen exposure management, incident response, and integrated risk management capabilities.

ServiceNow also announced its planned acquisition of Armis for $7.75bn, its largest acquisition to date by deal value. Armis is a security platform that discovers, monitors, and protects connected devices (IT, OT, IoT, IoMT, etc.) across an organization's network, o ff ering asset visibility and cyber risk management to secure the entire attack surface. Founded in 2015, Armis serves 35%+ of the Fortune 100 and 7 of the Fortune 10, with 950 employees globally - it generates $340mn ARR with 50%+ yoy growth.

With the acquisition, ServiceNow plans to expand its security work fl ow o ff erings in cyber-physical security for critical infrastructure and advance security and vulnerability response across connected devices. Armis delivers a view of an organization's assets as a network of connected entities (devices, services, applications, identities, and data fl ows) and the paths between them, driven by graph-based technology. ServiceNow believes that the intended acquisition would expand its security o ff erings, particularly in cyber exposure management and cyber-physical security, by integrating Armis's real-time asset discovery and threat intelligence with ServiceNow's automated work fl ows for proactive security and risk reduction. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

valuation methodology is based on non-GAAP P/E. We apply a 40x P/E multiple to ServiceNow's SNTM (Q5-Q8) earnings. ServiceNow's EPS growth is ~30% above the cohort - as such, we apply a 20% premium to ServiceNow to account for EPS growth, partly o ff set by limited visibility into the evolving pricing model.

Slowing momentum in new market expansion reducing growth trajectory: n ServiceNow's growth trajectory is signi fi cantly in fl uenced by its ability to expand into new markets through new product o ff erings and industry verticals - these new markets are often highly competitive, with established players specializing in HR, CRM, or industry-speci fi c solutions. Slowing momentum would likely make it di ffi cult for ServiceNow to sustain its 20%+ growth watermark. Lack of adoption of AI solutions: ServiceNow's strategic direction and future n growth are increasingly tied to its ability to integrate and drive the adoption of AI solutions across its platform. Moreover, ServiceNow's traditional o ff erings are seat-based solutions, which may come under pressure if its not o ff set by adoption of ServiceNow's agentic o ff erings. Limited margin expansion: Higher expense growth from S&M e ff orts or agentic n investments limiting margin expansion. Also, large scale M&A transactions may be viewed as a medium-term risk to margin expansion.

We assume coverage of Snow fl ake (SNOW) with a Buy rating and 28% upside to our 12-month price target of $286. We see three primary drivers of upside in 2026: 1) We believe cloud RDBMS migrations are picking up due to AI, and that Snow fl ake will continue to capture outsized share of the cloud data platform market and associated data analytics projects. 2) Our analysis of customer cohorts suggest that existing customers are poised to contribute greater dollars in FY27, as net customer adds over the past two years scale more materially and Snow fl ake continues to drive expansion within its higher spend customers. 3) We believe Snow fl ake has made meaningful progress on closing the functionality gap with Databricks for ML/AI workloads; and that Snow fl ake-heavy customers are more likely to consider using Snow fl ake for new ML/AI workloads.

Over the long term, we monitor two key risks: i) whether Snow fl ake's pace of new customer acquisition could slow as Databricks continues to build out its roadmap for a set of workloads that historically accrued to Snow fl ake, from its relatively stronger beachhead in ML/AI (which has increased in strategic importance for customers); ii) whether Iceberg reduces switching cost for Snow fl ake and other data platform vendors, such that the industry becomes more competitive over time, driving higher R&D intensity or M&A intensity relative to the last 10 years.

- 1. Continued market share gains as AI catalyzes next phase of cloud migrations We believe cloud RDBMS migrations are picking up due to AI, and that Snow fl ake will continue to capture outsized share of the cloud data platform market and associated data analytics projects. As enterprises continue to migrate workloads from on-premise to cloud environments, Snow fl ake's SAM within the broader TAM goes up. During the early stages of migrations, companies typically shift existing databases to the cloud in phases, leading to steadily rising consumption after initial deployment. Thus, the key opportunity for Snow fl ake is when these companies modernize their data architecture by consolidating silos, rebuilding pipelines, and enabling new analytics and AI use cases. As more enterprises progress through digital transformation programs, Snow fl ake bene fi ts not just from new customer acquisitions but also expanding consumption as data volumes, concurrency, and workloads grow in the cloud.

We estimate that the RDBMS TAM is 55% cloud today (vs. 45% on-prem); up from <30% cloud in 2019.

We believe AI is accelerating a new wave of cloud migrations in both scope and urgency. The fi rst generation of cloud migrations (2010-2021) centered on infrastructure o ffl oad. In legacy databases, compute and storage were coupled, meaning capacity had to be provisioned for peak demand and workloads compete for resources. Snow fl ake's multi-cluster, shared data architecture eliminated these constraints by letting multiple virtual warehouses query the same data simultaneously to run workloads in parallel without performance degradation. This next phase of cloud migrations catalyzed by AI is data-centric. AI workloads depend on massive, uni fi ed data lakes for model training, fi ne-tuning, and retrieval-augmented inference. Enterprises that previously had fragmented or on-prem data architectures are increasingly focused on centralizing on the cloud to enable data readiness. Snow fl ake sits at the intersection

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 of AI-driven data movement and enterprise cloud modernization - its cloud-native data platform for uni fi ed, queryable data across clouds allows enterprises to centralize access without centralizing infrastructure, making it the 'data plane' for AI workloads. We believe Snow fl ake will continue to capture share of customer migrations from legacy databases driven by the AI-centric migration push, independent of Snow fl ake's AI innovation (discussed in more detail below).

Postgres/Crunchy Data expands its TAM by ~2x - while Snow fl ake has historically operated solely in the OLAP market, its acquisition of Crunchy Data enhances its PostgreSQL capabilities (the standard for OLTP databases) and accelerates its entry into transactional data markets. The solution extends native support for transactional, hybrid, and analytical workloads on a single platform, enabling organizations to build AI agents and intelligent apps directly on operational data. The acquisition complements Snow fl ake's Unistore (which uni fi es transactional and analytical data) by providing an enterprise-ready solution speci fi cally for transactional applications requiring PostgreSQL compatibility. While we believe it is unlikely that Snow fl ake captures mission-critical OLTP workloads near term, as companies standardize around platforms we believe Snow fl ake could be a bene fi ciary.

We note that this correlation likely diminishes going forward given hyperscaler exposure to AI training revenue Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

- 2. Recent new customer momentum should drive a particularly strong expansion cohort in 2026

New customer acquisition lags ramped revenue contribution due the natural progression of customer adoption; net customer adds over the past two years give us con fi dence in Snow fl ake's medium-term growth outlook as these customers scale more materially. When new customers join Snow fl ake, they typically do not rip and replace the entire on-premise data warehouse immediately. This is especially true for enterprises with signi fi cant data volumes and intricate infrastructures. Rather, they start by migrating certain workloads and running them in Snow fl ake, over time increasing their usage. Snow fl ake's consumption-based pricing model supports this dynamic, recognizing revenue as and when customers migrate more workloads. Snow fl ake is focused on accelerating migration timelines, evidenced in its acquisition of the technology behind the Datometry software migration solution, which reduces time to move from legacy data warehouses to Snow fl ake up to 4x while reducing costs by up

2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 to 90% - nonetheless, over the medium term we continue to expect more staggered migration timelines. We highlight select customer examples below: Financial Services: This customer previously leveraged a two-tier architecture using n Hortonworks and Cloudera, and completed historical forensic analysis on Hadoop. Given an enterprise-wide push to cloud, this customer chose Snow fl ake as its preferred data warehouse. Initially, they utilized both storage and compute with Snow fl ake, though is now shifting to Iceberg tables. Nonetheless, Snow fl ake remains the preferred ingest and query engine - in fact, this customer expects to more than double its contract with Snow fl ake.

IT Consulting: This customer has been with Snow fl ake since 2021, prior to which the n company had traditional enterprise data warehouses across each of its business units (i.e. Teradata for the retail business and SAP Business Warehouse for utilities), with 1.5 PB of data across the organization. In order to communicate between the on-prem database, the customer had to create another layer on top necessitating a vast amount of data engineering, as well as another layer to connect this data to CRM software (i.e. Salesforce). Snow fl ake enabled the customer to migrate its workloads from on-prem to the cloud, but the customer noted that this was not a simple 'lift and shift.' Migrating these workloads took time - whereas some data from established software providers (i.e. Salesforce, SAP) was relatively straightforward, other custom systems (i.e. PLM and manufacturing execution systems) took time to build the data engineering connectors. Moreover, the customer noted that the cost was prohibitive to simply

lifting and shifting all of its data. In the past, Snow fl ake has noted that the dollar-weighted average time from start date to contract consumption run rate can be up to ~270 days, with a pickup in contribution ramping 1-2 years post customer acquisition. We see an ~80% correlation between net customer adds (on a quarter over quarter basis) and product revenue growth yoy on a two year lagged basis (to account for the lagged nature of new customers to revenue.) Net customers adds over the past two years suggest upside to Street estimates over the next 2 years.

In addition to migrations, we also expect continued expansion from broadening use cases among Snow fl ake's entrenched customer base. That is, even once migrations take place, Snow fl ake continues to grow with its customers by adding more data to the platform and driving new use cases. In fact, Snow fl ake has made several changes to its sales motion to incentivize additional consumption on the platform, establishing targeted specialist sales teams focused on particular applications (rather than general sales mastering all product capabilities). We expect these changes to the sales motion to continue to drive higher consumption on the platform.

Snow fl ake's top 25 customers are spending $20mn+ on average; the average Forbes Global 2000 customer (of which Snow fl ake has ~760, contributing ~40% of total revenue) is spending ~$2mn; and average revenue per customer across all customer sizes is ~$340k. We believe there is signi fi cant room to expand customer spend, and look to Oracle database as a case study of where product revenue can go - we think this is a 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

good proxy given Oracle's historical entrenchment with database customers is indicative of Snow fl ake's upper bound should there be consolidation in the data platform space around Snow fl ake. Oracle Database has ~$13bn of revenue and tens of thousands of customers - given the exact disclosure is limited, we estimate total customers between 20-40k. This implies average database revenue per customer somewhere between $500-900k (vs. Snow fl ake ARPC ~$340k). Even assuming customers remain stable at ~12k (to be clear, we expect continued customer growth of 10%+ in the medium term), the high end of our Oracle ARPC estimates imply that product revenue can get to $10bn+ (Snow fl ake's target set during the 2021 Investor Day to achieve by CY28/FY29), and this milestone is easier to achieve when accounting for continued customer acquisition. We note this analysis does not account for gains related to AI services, which we believe drives upside to ARPC.

3. Technology innovation brings AI/ML into the SAM for the fi rst time in 2026 Snow fl ake has signi fi cantly evolved its platform to manage diverse workloads and address the increasing demands of AI workloads by focusing on a uni fi ed, scalable, and cost-e ffi cient architecture, alongside the introduction of specialized AI/ML features and services. Given the importance of data architecture in an AIfi rst world, and the pace of change in the ecosystem, Snow fl ake has been focused on increased product innovation: Snow fl ake historically positioned itself as a cloud data warehouse; the platform was n optimized primarily for analytical, batch-oriented workloads on structured data. Over the last two years, Snow fl ake has rearchitected key layers of its platform to evolve from 'warehouse' to an AI Data Cloud powering agentic applications, real-time systems, and ML workloads.

Snow fl ake introduced lakehouse capabilities, supporting open table formats like n Iceberg and Delta, external data sources, and unstructured data handling. It also introduced hybrid transactional features (Unistore, Hybrid Tables, and now Snow fl ake Postgres via the acquisition of Crunchy Data) enabling operational and low-latency workloads to run next to analytical data.

Snow fl ake expanded its capabilities in the data engineering and integration market n it acquired Datavolo in November 2024, which built data fl ow infrastructure to support the creation, management, and observability of multimodal data pipelines for enterprise AI. Snow fl ake has productized Datavolo's technology as Snow fl ake OpenFlow, which serves as their strategic entry point into the data integration market (~$15bn TAM). OpenFlow provides hundreds of ready-to-use connectors for data sources (i.e. Box, Google Ads, Microsoft Dataverse, Microsoft SharePoint, Oracle, Salesforce Data Cloud, ServiceNow, Workday, and Zendesk, etc.) to accelerate data integration. It enables secure automation of data integration from virtually any source while keeping data centralized across the enterprise lakehouse. This technology gives Snow fl ake more access into the entire data lifecycle, rather than engaging with the data only when it reaches the analytics phase. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

| AI Exp e ri e n ce ( Sn o wfl a k e In te lli ge n ce) | Snowsight                       | · Web interface providing unified environment to interact with Semantic search over objects                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| AI Exp e ri e n ce ( Sn o wfl a k e In te lli ge n ce) | Insights & Analytics Agents     | · Automated analysis, statistical summaries, etc.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| AI Exp e ri e n ce ( Sn o wfl a k e In te lli ge n ce) | Engineering & Ops Copilots      | · Query debugging, pipeline generation, observability insights                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |

Snowpark is the developer framework that allows data engineers and developers to write data pipelines and ML work fl ows using familiar languages like Python, Java, and Scala, directly within Snow fl ake platform to process data and build applications directly within Snow fl ake. Its technical capabilities for AI/ML include in-platform processing for complex data transformations, feature engineering, and model inference, which reduces latency and streamlines the ML lifecycle. Snowpark ML, a Python library, speci fi cally supports end-to-end ML work fl ows, allowing users to leverage popular Python frameworks for preprocessing, feature engineering, and training. For advanced AI workloads, Snowpark Container Services (SPCS) facilitates the deployment and management of containerized applications, including custom LLMs and open-source models, securely within Snow fl ake, with support for GPU instances. Snowpark also supports model deployment as User-De fi ned Functions (UDFs) for real-time inference and integrates with tools like MLFlow for model

lifecycle management, including versioning and experimentation. Snowpark is currently ~3% of Snow fl ake's product revenue (or ~$130mn for FY26).

- Sano fi : This customer replaced its managed Spark solution with Snow fl ake, resulting n in a 50% in improvement in performance. Sano fi is developing an enteprise-wide data processing platform, creating a web application for medical professions to input query fi lters related to diseases, drugs, or procedures and identify patient cohorts meeting speci fi c criteria to analyze real-world clinical data. The web application processes billions of records to generate these insights. Previously, Sano fi 's data architecture relied on a managed Spark engine as its computational layer. This strategy led to issues with manual deployment and maintenance, resource 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

scalability, pipeline failures, concurrency issues during peak usage, and data movement complexities between platforms. It chose Snow fl ake for one of its redesigns, leveraging Snowpark as the computational layer for Python code within the Snow fl ake data platform, eliminating the need for data transfer and ensuring governance over data and libraries. This migration from managed Spark to Snowpark resulted in 50% performance improvement.

Snow fl ake Cortex is a fully managed AI service that integrates ready-to-use AI and ML capabilities directly into Snow fl ake Data Cloud. It o ff ers a suite of pre-built functions that leverage leading LLMs from various providers, enabling natural language processing (NLP) tasks directly via SQL or Python (Cortex AISQL). Capabilities include text analysis such as summarization, sentiment analysis, entity extraction, and classi fi cation, as well as translation and natural language querying. Notable features include: 1) ML functions for traditional tasks like forecasting, anomaly detection, and classi fi cation, o ff ering pre-built models for common business needs; 2) Cortex Search, which provides AI-driven 'fuzzy' search across text data using hybrid search technology (vector and keyword search) and semantic re-ranking; 3) Cortex Analyst for natural language querying of structured data by translating questions into SQL; and 4) Cortex Agents for building production-ready AI applications that can reason across data and utilize tools like Cortex

Analyst and Cortex Search. Cortex combines structured data (via Cortex Analyst) and unstructured data (via Cortex Search) to enable natural language queries, a key evolution to Snow fl ake's platform which has historically been more focused on structured data. Cortex has a usage-based pricing model, charging in credits per million tokens (for LLM functions) and per GB per month (for Cortex search). Other AI o ff erings include Snow fl ake Intelligence, which enables business users to use AI-driven natural language to interact with data and Document AI, which extracts structured and unstructured data from various document formats. On adoption, 7,300+ accounts are using Snow fl ake's AI every week and 28% of all deployed use cases are now leveraging AI.

Our industry conversations suggest that Databricks is still the superior tool for ML/AI workloads, and we expect Databricks to continue to innovate to maintain a technical lead that is meaningful enough to drive competitive di ff erentiation. In this context, we believe Snow fl ake will still be able to capture some lower-hanging ML/AI workloads; for example, those within customers that have already chosen to standardize on Snow fl ake and that do not want to make their environment more complex for what they view as only a marginal performance bene fi t from Databricks. We view 2026 as the fi rst year where Snow fl ake will have access to a portion of these workloads for the fi rst time. The key longer term will be whether Snow fl ake will be able to further close the gap with Databricks such that it can capture higher performance ML/AI use cases, and win new customer opportunities for customers that consider ML/AI to be key criteria for their data warehouse provider.

A note on Iceberg and risks to the model: As discussed above, Snow fl ake introduced support for Apache Iceberg in 2025, an open-source table format for data lakes that allows di ff erent query engines (including Snow fl ake) to directly read and write to the same data fi les in cloud object storage. Snow fl ake's support for Apache Iceberg tables (with 1,200+ accounts using it) allows customers to work with open data as they would with data stored in Snow fl ake, preserving enterprise-grade performance and security 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

while avoiding vendor lock-in. Prior to its support for Iceberg, customers had to ingest data into Snow fl ake's platform and pay for storage, which historically has been ~11% of Snow fl ake's product revenue (at much lower margins than core compute revenue). To date, we believe Iceberg adoption is still very early; Snow fl ake has not seen a headwind to storage revenue from Iceberg support, with storage revenue growing in line with the rest of the business. Over time, we expect storage revenue to decline as more customers leverage Iceberg, though note that it will not necessarily go to zero given the technical involvement of managing the data in Iceberg. More broadly, we think the open data format expands Snow fl ake's addressable workload opportunity, potentially yielding additional consumption upside.

The push towards Iceberg lowers the switching cost between data platforms, as data gravity/storage stickiness is no longer a reason to standardize on a speci fi c vendor. While this increases the pressure to stay ahead of competition, we believe that performance and versatility of the platform become the factors that drive stickiness. Snow fl ake continuously enhances its platform through annual hardware and software improvements. Its latest Gen2 Warehouses signi fi cantly enhance performance for analytics and data engineering workloads - generally available since May 2025, Gen2 Warehouses consistently demonstrate performance improvements, with an average gain of approximately 30% across various query patterns and up to 2.1 times faster execution for core analytics scenarios. We believe that these performance improvements incentivize customers to add more workloads to the platform, even if customers are not storing data on Snow fl ake.

Moreover, data sharing is supportive of stickiness on Snow fl ake's platform, with 3.5k marketplace listings and ~40% of customers with at least 1 stable edge (a data/native app share between provider and consumer customers that generates at least 20 compute jobs consuming resources/generating revenue over two consecutive three-week periods). This design enables cross-ecosystem value creation, where data sharing between enterprises creates a web of interconnected relationships, positioning Snow fl ake as the central data exchange layer for industries and increasing stickiness. Competition from cloud service providers (CSPs) and Databricks: Snow fl ake n faces signi fi cant competitive risks from both established cloud service providers (CSPs) and Databricks, as these entities o ff er alternative or overlapping data management and analytics solutions that can attract or retain customers. CSPs provide native data warehousing, analytics, and data lake services, and can leverage their infrastructure to o ff er competitive pricing and bundling options. Databricks is a risk to Snow fl ake particularly in the realm of uni fi ed data platforms and AI/ML workloads. While Snow fl ake has been expanding its AI/ML capabilities, Databricks has a perceived lead and a more mature integrated o ff ering for these advanced analytics use cases.

Adverse changes in the IT spending environment or further optimization cycles n in cloud spending: Given Snow fl ake's business model is reliant on customer consumption of its platform, adverse changes in the broader IT spending environment or intensi fi ed cloud spending optimization cycles pose risks, either through reduced new customer acquisition, decreased expansion from existing customers, budget cuts/project delays, or increased scrutiny on spend. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

We assume coverage of Workday with a Neutral rating (from Buy) and 15% upside to our 12-month price target of $238. Relative to scaled SaaS peers, we believe Workday faces two challenges: 1) its core TAM of HCM is smaller and more penetrated than CRM and ERP, which may make it more challenging to realize growth from share gains tied to the SaaS transition; 2) its AI strategy has taken longer to crystallize, and we expect 2026 will be key to integrate recent acquisitions such as Sana while also replatforming the underlying tech stack. With that said, we see the opportunity to become more positive on the stock through 2026, primarily because we believe Workday is taking steps to meaningfully improve its positioning with AI that could ultimately drive stable and improving revenue growth beyond 13-14%. There are signs of stabilization and improvement in key metrics over the last four quarters (albeit with some noise tied to M&A and AI), likely in part because cohort renewals have stabilized (we believe

the 3-year cohorts renewing in 2023 and 2024 were particularly under pressure given overbuying in 2020 and 2021). We look to gauge to what extent Workday's expanded platform can drive improved wallet share capture as customers assess next-gen o ff erings in the O ffi ce of the CFO.
