Workday gained outsized share between 2010-2020 in the HCM market, as its cloud-native platform o ff ered performance and cost bene fi ts over legacy competitors. During that decade, Workday also introduced new modules to build a broader back o ffi ce suite: this includes Payroll in 2011, Learning in 2016, and Planning in 2018. Although Workday launched Financial Management in 2008, the Financials Suite (FINS+) remains ~25% of revenue. Consistent with the rest of SaaS, Workday's growth has slowed from >30% pre-COVID to 14.5% in FY26E: this is a combination of 1) post COVID normalization, where customers went from a period of elevated buying and hiring to period of heightened budget scrutiny and layo ff s; and 2) mechanical share gains slowing.

More speci fi c to HCM , Workday mechanically gained share as the industry transitioned from on prem (where Workday had no exposure) to cloud (where Workday had outsized share), and COVID resulted in above-trend adoption. Simultaneous with the cloud transition, legacy competitors have also introduced cloud products, including SAP SuccessFactors, ADP Workforce, and Oracle HCM. While both these trends apply to the SaaS application space broadly, we believe the core HCM TAM has seen outsized pressure: industry estimates from Gartner suggest that HCM is in the top quartile of most penetrated with more than 80% to the cloud. Additionally, the TAM screens as smaller relative to categories such as CRM and ERP, and our industry conversations suggest it is generally less strategic or less of a focus for AI-driven productivity gains.

The ERP TAM in which Workday's FINS+ o ff ering competes is less penetrated (~40%); the business risk associated with an ERP implementation is enough to drive companies to delay them, and data/compliance laws are headwinds. The competitive landscape is nuanced, including new peers such as OneStream (OS, covered by Adam Hotchkiss) with high win rates and pricing pressure from incumbents like SAP and Oracle. International ERP is particularly di ffi cult to compete in, both because of legal/compliance di ff erences and entrenched international players. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

launched its fi rst AI product in 2015, but started meaningfully leveling up their AI strategy over the past year. Their strategy is to use Workday's consolidated data with a semantic model on top to give context for AI actions and provide more customized experiences. For example, in the future, a job candidate could have a 'personal' AI recruiter and share feedback with them after the interview. Reaching this strategic vision and preempting disruption from AI-native competitors has required signi fi cant rethinking of Workday's tech foundations. This included hiring a new CTO and President (both from Google), re-architecting the platform to make their data foundations stronger (including partnerships with Snow fl ake and Databricks), pursuing tuck-in M&A, and experimenting with fl ex credits as a complement to their traditionally subscription-based model. Workday has >$150mn in AI ARR (as of F2Q26, more than 3X

yoy); 15+ out-of-the-box agents; a hyper scale, real-time, zero-copy data platform in 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 Workday Data Cloud; 35% of customer expansions including at least one AI product; and >75% of core customers using Workday Illuminate AI. In addition, according to the company, it will gain 3K connections shipped through the proposed Pipedream acquisition (pending, expected close before Jan 31, 2026), which would otherwise have taken years to build.

In the context of the core drivers of the business being less additive than before, we highlight the following areas of opportunity: If Workday di ff erentiates itself in AI such that it is able to capture new value through 1. being a central pane of glass for managing HCM-related or O ffi ce-of-the-CFO related agents, it could become the orchestration layer for HR Delivery where outsized value accrues Workday's international business remains smaller than peers at 25% of revenues, 2. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 compared to Salesforce's 34% and SAP's non-EMEA revenues of 52%.

The company could surprise to the upside on ERP share if vendor consolidation 3. outweighs feature-completeness, and if they are able to realize new FINSfi rst wins. Their front-line worker strategy could allow them to continue to take share of HCM 4. in previously under-penetrated categories Even as Workday's revenue growth has slowed into the teens, there remains 5. potential for outsized margin expansion. Workday benchmarks well compared to large cap peers. Workday in particular has begun to address its low GAAP margins and high stock based comp, with less dilution in recent years and a ramping buyback. GAAP SG&A likely has room for improvement, and P&T expense will become more e ffi cient with the rollout of innovation centers in EMEA and continued optimization of their employee base.

In an upside case, Workday has the potential to look like Intuit in the 2017-2019 era, when that company exited a period of macro headwinds (in Intuit's case two bad tax seasons), re-invented itself (in Intuit's case through major divestitures), and was able to re-accelerate growth even as margins continued to improve. Intuit became a compelling EPS and EBIT ramp story that drove a subsequent re-rating.

We assume coverage of Figma with a Neutral rating (unchanged) and a 12-month price target of $40. We view Figma as a leading asset in collaborative design for product development, with particularly di ff erentiated IP in synchronizing changes across multiple users and its web-based front end. This technical foundation has supported the platform's expansion beyond design into adjacent work fl ows across the product development lifecycle, with products like FigJam, Dev Mode, Figma Sites, and Figma Buzz. As a result, Figma has captured a wider range of product development personas, with non-designers already representing two-thirds of MAUs. Long-term fundamentals are compelling, where we see a multi-year opportunity for Figma to deepen wallet share within large accounts (Customers with $10K+ ARR), expand into adjacent work fl ows, and capture new revenue streams from AI (Figma Make). Please see our August 2025 note for more details about the company.

Scaling revenue contribution from AI. Figma is currently focused on AI adoption without explicit monetization to o ff set inferencing costs, driving margin compression over the next 12-24 months. Early indicators are encouraging, with total paid customers increasing to 540K in 3Q25 (vs. 450K in 1Q25), driven in part by Figma Make adoption, and 30% of $100K+ ARR Customers now creating in Figma Make weekly. While the product is still early (GA in July 2025) and the consumption-based credit model is still evolving, Figma Make may translate to more material upsell, seat expansion, and incremental usage-based revenue.

personas. Prior product launches such as Dev mode have demonstrated Figma's ability to drive material revenue uplift through cross sell, with NRR reaccelerating from 122% to 134% in F24. However, it is unclear to us whether new o ff erings introduced in May 2025 - such as Figma Buzz, which targets more peripheral personas involved in product development like marketers - can achieve comparable levels of adoption or upsell / cross-sell momentum to prior product cycles.

Better-than-anticipated pricing power: Figma implemented its fi rst pricing and packaging changes in March 2025, introducing multi-product seats bundles and 20-33% price increase for Full Seat licenses (+33% for Professional / +22% for Organization / +20% for Enterprise). We will fully anniversary the pricing and packaging tailwind by 1Q26. Given the company's limited operating history with pricing and packaging changes, we have limited visibility around customer price sensitivity - particularly as industry conversations suggest Figma is already perceived as premium-priced. However, should these changes be absorbed with minimal friction, it would signal greater pricing power and contribute more meaningfully to revenue.

We are Neutral rated and lower our 12-month price target to $40 (vs. $54 prior), based on 16x EV/sales (down from 20x on refreshed comps), a ~20% discount to NET and CRWD on EV/sales/growth on SNTM sales growth given that Figma is earlier in scaling and in its platform evolution. We also include an updated share count that re fl ects full 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953 potential dilution, to be consistent with the rest of our coverage. Key downside risks: 1) Pressure from newly introduced pricing and packaging, or intensifying price competition, 2) Product / market fi t misalignment, 3) Escalated AI investments may pressure margins without su ffi cient top-line contribution, 4) Increased competition from AI-native players.

Key upside risks: 1) Better-than-anticipated pricing power, 2) Outsized momentum from adoption of emerging products and expansion into design-adjacent personas, 3) Earlier-than-expected AI monetization, and 4) Minimal disruption risk from AI-native players. Our FY25/26/27 revenue estimates remain largely unchanged and we introduce an FY28 revenue estimate of $1,848mn.

We assume coverage of Navan at a $30 price target (unchanged, 68% upside) and a Buy rating . We view Navan as a compelling share gain story as the fi rst scaled alternative to legacy travel and expense tools. We expect to see an elevated pace of share gain over the next 3 years as companies solve for AI adoption and cost controls in their back o ffi ce tools, at the same time as Navan expands its network of travel inventory. Furthermore, Navan has the opportunity to grow beyond their historical sweet spot of mid-market and tech-forward customers to move both upmarket (enterprise traction only just beginning), downmarket (still under penetrated in SMBs, new product-led motion will help), and internationally (crucial to addressing more global organizations). Taken together, we expect ~15% customer growth, which when combined with ~110% NRR and some contribution from secular/TAM growth should drive a sustainable 25% CAGR over the next 3-5 years.

For more details on the company, see our November report (link) and our Jan 7 NDR report (link). Catalyst Path: Navan is down 28% since its IPO price of $25. In our view, the underperformance of the stock re fl ects three concerns, each of which have catalysts that could improve sentiment and allow the stock to rerate toward our view of intrinsic value. We highlight the following catalysts for the stock:

Establishing a robust operating history in the public markets. Navan announced a 1. CFO transition in December and operates in the macro-sensitive business travel market. We believe the company has detailed forecasting algorithms and a good baseline understanding of its customers' spending patters that will help it beat and raise even in a period of executive transition. Our research colleagues' positive views on both the economy and industry-speci fi c backdrop inform our con fi dence our base case that the business travel TAM should continue to grow. Speci fi cally, our economists expect strong global growth in 2026 (2.8% vs. the Street at 2.5%) and our airlines and lodging teams expect acceleration in airline capacity growth and RevPAR growth, respectively, into 2026. Progress on margins: Navan expects to be FCF breakeven in FY27 (ends Jan 2027). 2. 2aeb9e8b174644998c7303f5a989d953

Consistent with other 30%+ Software models, we believe the company will realize a more material in fl ection in FCF post its current investment cycle. Navan's LTV:CAC is >3.0x vs. median app software peers at ~2.0x. - Additional large customer wins: Navan recently announced GE and Visa as 3. customers. We believe being publicly-traded and progress in launching enterprise features will help with more marquee customer wins, in addition to existing fl agship customers such as Canva.

We are Buy rated on Navan. Our (unchanged) 12-month Price Target of $30 is based on 7.8x Q5-Q8 EV / Sales. This implies a NTM EV / Sales / Growth multiple of 0.30x. Key downside risks include: travel spend volatility associated with the macroeconomic cycle or natural disasters/geopolitical events, yield contraction, AI native disruption, elongated path to pro fi tability.

Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%-50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%-30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%-15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.
